H-NS

  • of exogenous and endogenous hydrophobic electrophiles Involved in ﬁrst step of GMP biosynthesis from IMP ; induced by low pH during anaerobic-growth Catalyzes the irreversible NADPH-dependent deamination of GMP to IMP ; functions in the conversion of nucleobase , nucleoside , and nucleotide derivatives of G-to-A nucleotides and in maintaining the intracellular balance of A and G nucleotides DNA gyrase negatively supercoils closed circular double-stranded DNA in an ATP-dependent manner and also catalyzes the interconversion of other topological isomers of double-stranded DNA rings , including catenanes and knotted rings See GyrA Uses temp-induced exposure of structured hydrophobic domains to capture and stabilize early unfolding protein intermediates under severe thermal stress ; rapidly releases them once stress has abated and is induced by heat-shock Induced by low pH during anaerobic-growth and at the stationary phase Periplasmic protein that may be involved in acid resistance ; 43,867.66 Flavohemoprotein P24232 323 Continued on facing pag Has possible histone-like function and may be a global transcriptional-regulator through its ability to-bind to curved DNA sequences , which are found in regions upstream of a certain subset of promoters ; subject to transcriptional autorepression by binding preferentially to the upstream region of its own gene recognizing two segments of DNA on both sides of a bend centered around position 150 ; the hns mutant exhibit derepression not only of csgBA , hdeAB , mcc , and osmY but also of the expression of at least 22 S-controlled genes , including S itself ; increases during phosphate limitation and phosphonate growth Involved in purine salvage pathway and acts exclusively on hypoxanthine Involved in the maturation of iron-sulfur cluster-containing proteins ; seems to help targeting proteins to be folded toward HscA Redox regulated molecular chaperone ; protects both thermally unfolding and oxidatively damaged proteins from irreversible aggregation ; plays an important role in the bacterial defense system toward oxidative-stress ; induced by heat-shock Chaperone subunit of a proteasome-like degradation complex ; increases following exposure to the uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation 2,4-dinitrophenol Protease subunit of a proteasome-like degradation complex ; increases following exposure to the uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation 2,4-dinitrophenol Molecular chaperone ; has ATPase activity ; increases following exposure to the uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation 2,4-dinitrophenol but decreases during phosphate limitation late Participates in the periplasmic electron-transferring activity of hydrogenase 2 during its catalytic turnover Required for the maturation of the three NiFe hydrogenases ; exhibits a low intrinsic GTPase activity ; affects some aspect of the processing of hydrogenases 1 and 2 , perhaps nickel incorporation into the Associates with aggregated proteins , together with IbpB , to stabilize and protect them from irreversible denaturation and extensive proteolysis during heat-shock and oxidative-stress ; aggregated proteins bound to the IbpAB complex are more efﬁciently refolded and reactivated by the ATP-dependent chaperone systems ClpB and DnaK/DnaJ/GrpE ; its activity is ATP independent ; IbpAB increase in overexpression of heterologous proteins and biopolymers See IbpA ; decreases during phosphate limitation early Inhibition of this enzyme by phosphorylation regulates the branch point between the Krebs cycle and the glyoxylate bypass , which is an alternate route that accumulates carbon for biosynthesis when acetate is the sole carbon source for growth ; increases during high-cell-density cultivation but decreases during phosphate limitation Fermentative lactate dehydrogenase ; increases during phosphate limitation and at low pH under anaerobic conditions Catalyzes the formation of   • H-NS : A UNIVERSAL REGULATOR The effect of the bacterial heat-stable nucleoid-structuring ( H-NS ) protein on gene expression is overwhelmingly negative and extends throughout the genome , pointing to an almost universal role for this nucleoid-associated protein as a transcriptional-repressor . [15100692]
  • The nucleoid-associated protein H-NS is a global transcriptional-repressor that controls the expression of several environmentally regulated genes . [23873909]

  • More than ten transcription regulators including EvgA , YdeO , GadE , TorR , H-NS , PhoP , RpoS , CRP , MnmE , GadX , and GadW have been found to participate in the regulation of gadE during various circumstances of acid stresses through at least ﬁve different regulatory circuits ( Ma et al. , 2004 ; Sayed and Foster , 2009 ) . [23874328]
  • Involvement of EvgA , YdeO , H-NS , CRP , GadX , as well as a small RNA DsrA in the regulation of the mdtEF gene in the same operon has also been reported ( Nishino and Yamaguchi , 2002 , 2004 ; Oshima et al. , 2006 ; Nishino et al. , 2008a , b , 2009 , 2011 ) . [23874328]

  • After leucine-responsive protein , H-NS and σs , NhaR and RcsB are the fourth and ﬁfth regulators of osmC transcription to have been identiﬁed The participation of so many factors in the regulation of osmC illustrates the notion of cooperation of global regulators in the ﬁne-tuning of stress-inducible genes ( Bouvier et al. , 1998 ; Hengge-Aronis , 1999 ) . [11577158]
  • These include the transcription factor FNR that mediates anaerobic regulation ( Unden and Schirawski , 1997 ) , the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , which activates transcription of catabolic operons ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ) , and the nucleoid-associated protein H-NS ( Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ) . [10564497]
  • Although the transcription factor Fis helps to recruit RNAP to rrn P1 promoters ( Bokal et al. , 1995 ) , and the nucleoid protein H-NS can inhibit rRNA promoter activity ( Afflerbach et al. , 1998 ) , most regulation of rRNA transcription is not a function of the action of classical activator or repressor proteins ( Bartlett and Gourse , 1994 ; Murray et al. , 2003b ; Schneider et al. , 2003b ; Murray and Gourse , 2004 ) . [15294157]
  • During growth in minimal medium , the leucine-responsive protein has been shown to repress the transcription of osmC and to activate that of osmC , p '' p # and the nucleoid-associated protein H-NS represses transcription from both promoters ( Bouvier et al. , 1998 ) . [11577158]
  • The other is the nucleoid-associated protein H-NS or StpA , which binds to the promoter region of the ydiV gene and may negatively E regulate its transcription ( Uyar et al. , 2009 ; Kahramanoglou et al. , 2011 ) . [22461489]
  • Pleiotropic effects of increased ArcZ expression Pioneering discoveries in the ﬁeld of sRNA-mediated gene regulation were based on fortuitous overexpression of afore unknown sRNA genes in E. coli , e.g. the discoveries of the micF or dsrA sRNA genes through their multicopy effects on OmpF or H-NS protein synthesis ( Mizuno et al. , 1984 ; Sledjeski and Gottesman , 1995 ) . [19732340]
  • Although the possibility exists that H-NS interacts directly with the gad promoters by negatively regulating their expression , it can also be hypothesized that this nucleoid protein indirectly affects the expression of gad via post-transcriptional regulation of RpoS ( ss ) expression ( Barth et al. , 1995 ; Yamashino et al. , 1995 ) . [10383761]
  • However , the effect of H-NS on gad expression is likely to be indirect because of the involvement of this protein in the post-transcriptional control of ss expression ( Barth et al. , 1995 ; Yamashino et al. , 1995 ) . [10383761]
  • Results sS and H-NS are implicated in hchA regulation In an early inventory of genes regulated by the nucleoidbinding protein H-NS , Yoshida and coworkers identiﬁed four unknown proteins whose production was upregulated in a Dhns mutant ( Yoshida et al. , 1993 ) . [16796689]
  • Many of the target genes regulated by LeuO are repressed by the pleiotropic H-NS ( heat-stable nucleoid structuring ) protein , and thus LeuO emerged as important H-NS antagonist and global regulator ( Hernandez-Lucas et al. , 2008 ; Shimada et al. , 2009 ; 2011 ) . [22295907]
  • This promoter is controlled by a number of global regulators such as CRP ( Yokota and Gots , 1970 ; Silverman and Simon , 1974 ) , heat-shock proteins DnaK , DnaJ and GrpE ( Shi et al. , 1992 ) and H-NS ( Bertin et al. , 1994 ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Yanagihara et al. , 1999 ) , as well as by several environmental signals such as temperature control ( Qualding and Stocker , 1962 ; Adler and Templeton , 1967 ) , high concentrations of inorganic salts , carbohydrates or alcohols ( Li et al. , 1993 ; Shi et al. , 1993 ) , growth-phase ( Nishimura and Hirota , 1989 ) , DNA supercoiling ( Li et al. , 1993 ; Shi et al. , 1993 ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Das et al. , 1998 ) , phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol synthesis ( Shi et al. , 1993 ; Mizushima et al. , 1995 ) , cell cycle control ( Morgan et al. , 1995 ; Prüß and Matsumura , 1996 ; Mizushima et al. , 1997 ) and quorum sensing ( Sperandio et al. , 2002 ) . [11929534]
  • labeled fragments ( 0.1 pmol ) were incubated with purified H-NS in the presence or absence of a competitor DNA ( a 233 bp synthetic non-curved DNA , designated $ 15-12 ; Yamada et al. 1990 ) , as indicated . [8455549, 8455549]
  • During the transition from exponential to stationary phase , when Fis levels are continually declining while elevated levels of the nucleoid-associated proteins Dps , IHF , HU , Hfq and H-NS are maintained ( Ali Azam et al. , 1999 ) , a global redistribution of chromosomal DNA branching can affect the accessibility of RNAP to numerous promoters to indirectly alter gene expression . [17768236]
  • The synthesis of IHF is indeed growth-phase regulated ( as is the case for the abundant H-NS and Dps proteins ; Almiron et al. , 1992 ) and an elevated concentration in stationary phase could help either to compact DNA , or protect it against chemical or physical attacks ( as was proposed for HU ; Boubrik & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1995 ) . [9837718]
  • Nucleoid compaction and DNA-associated proteins DNA-associated proteins such as H-NS , HU , IHF , and Fis have often been suggested to be responsible for DNA compaction in E. coli , based among other things on their colocalization with DNA in vivo ( Azam et al. , 2000 ) , on their occurrence in isolated nucleoids that are prepared in the absence of high salt concentrations ( Murphy and Zimmerman , 1997 ; Pettijohn , 1996 ) , and on their ability to bend or compact DNA in vitro ( Dame , 2005 ) . [16384714]
  • Also in accord , Brunetti et al. ( 2001 ) found that individual deletions of H-NS , HU , Fis , or IHF did not appear to change the large scale structure of the E. coli chromosome , based upon the lack of changes in the in vivo genomic fragmentation patterns by DNA gyrase in the presence of oxolinic acid . [16384714]
  • This observation is in marked contrast to the effects of other DNA-binding proteins such as H-NS and SASP , whose overexpression in actively growing E.coli leads to a massive DNA condensation and rapid loss of viability ( Setlow et al. , 1991 ; Spurio et al. , 1992 ) . [11230141]
  • In exponential phase E. coli cells , the order of intracellular concentration of these DNA-binding proteins is , in descending order , Fis , HU , StpA , H-NS and IHF ( Talukder et al. 1999 ) , among which HU , StpA , H-NS and IHF have been considered to participate in the condensation of genome DNA to form the compact nucleoid ( for reviews see Pettijohn 1982 , 1988 , 1996 ; Drlica & Rouviere-Yaniv 1987 ; Rouviere-Yaniv & Yaniv 1979 ; Murphy & Zimmerman 1997a , b ) . [10947847]
  • Falconi et al. ( 1991 ) suggested that H-NS potentiates the activity of transcriptional-repressors , Our results are in accordance with these hypotheses and suggest that H-NS binding might stabilise or mould bent DNA and thereby reduce the ability of Lrp to activate R N A polymerase , perhaps by using the elastic energy stored in the induced bend , as suggested by Wang and Calvo ( 1993b ) . [8152423]
  • Since H-NS is known to-bind DNA of incoming phage or plasmid directly ( Navarre et al. , 2006 ; Navarre et al. , 2007 ) this might result in redistribution of H-NS ( Doyle et al. , 2007 ; Dillon et al. , 2010 ) , allowing expression of the Cascade genes due to decreased local concentrations of the repressor . [20659289]
  • The target DNA sites in different operons shown to be bound by Lrp or H-NS have features in common and are often naturally bent DNA regions ; several protein molecules may bind to such curved DNA ( Yamada et al. , 1990 , 1991 ; Newman et al. , 1992 ; Owen-Hughes et al. , 1992 ; Calvo and Matthews , 1994 ; Zuber et al. , 1994 ) . [8890170]
  • Citation : Yun SH , Ji SC , Jeon HJ , Wang X , Kim SW , et al. ( 2012 ) The CnuK9E H-NS Complex Antagonizes DNA Binding of DicA and Leads to TemperatureDependent Filamentous Growth in E. coli . [23028867]
  • The H-NS is reported to form a dimer and to-bind to DNA nonspecifically , introducing significant compaction of DNA but no appreciable change in the linking number ( Lammi et al. , 1984 ; Falconi et al. , 1988 ; Spassky et al. , 1984 ) . [1452042]
  • The active form of H-NS is believed to be dimeric , although larger oligomers have been detected in solution ( Falconi et al. , 1988 ; Smyth et al. , 2000 ) . [16879983]
  • At present , it is not understood how recognition and/or activation by Es70 is avoided within the context of the cell , but the concentration of salts ( Ding et al. , 1995 ) , negative supercoiling of the DNA ( Kusano et al. , 1996 ) and protein factors such as H-NS ( Arnqvist et al. , 1994 ; Barth et al. , 1995 ; Hengge-Aronis , 1996a ) have been proposed to be involved . [9512707]
  • Although the RovA protein in Yersinia pseudotuberculosis has been shown to directly activate transcription by stimulating RNA polymerase ( RNAP ) in the absence of other accessory factors , it is thought that SlyA-type proteins generally activate transcription indirectly , by binding to DNA and modulating the activity of other factors such as PhoP or the nucleoid-associated protein H-NS ( Heroven et al. , 2004 ; Navarre et al. , 2005 ; Tran et al. , 2005 ) . [17892462]
  • It is known that the binding of FIS , H-NS , LRP and StpA occurs preferentially to curved or flexible DNA ( Hil-lebrand et al. , 2005 ; Pul et al. , 2005 ) . [18177266]
  • LRP and H-NS bind to the same DNA sequences , yet they differ in binding mechanisms In comparison with H-NS , which also binds to all seven rRNA P1 promoter upstream regions ( Hillebrand et al. , 2005 ) , LRP complexes were formed at notably lower ( 2-to 20-fold ) protein concentrations . [16238633]
  • In addition , the T7 5.5 protein binds to the H-NS protein and can inhibit its oligo-merization with DNA ( Ali et al. 2011 ) . [22327802]
  • This result is in agreement with previous data on H-NS , suggesting a co-operative binding of this protein to DNA ( Rimsky and Spassky , 1990 ; Lucht et al. , 1994 ) . [9987132]
  • As demonstrated before ( Hillebrand et al. , 2005 ) , H-NS binding occurred cooperatively , and a rather diffuse range of shifted DNA fragments with decreasing electrophoretic mobility is apparent at increasing protein concentrations . [16238633]
  • Further , it was proposed that LeuO acts as a positive regulator of the leu operon and leuO gene with activation based on transcription induced changes in DNA supercoiling and delimiting of H-NS spreading by LeuO ( Fang and Wu , 1998b ; Chen et al. , 2003 ; Chen and Wu , 2005 ) . [22295907]
  • This event is sensitive to topological changes in the DNA ( Glasgow et al. 1989 ) , and our result that increased osmZ gene dosage reduces the frequency of fimbrial phase variation can be explained by the effect of H-NS on DNA rigidity . [2177526]
  • H-NS can bind to DNA and form higher-order oligomeric H-NS complexes in a concentration-dependent manner , changing DNA topology and interfering with the action of other transcription factors ( Tupper et al. , 1994 ; Esposito et al. , 2002 ; Rimsky , 2004 ) . [17892462]
  • In vitro the formation of higher order structures of H-NS on the DNA is reduced at elevated temperatures ( 37 ∞ C versus 25 ∞ C ) and by increased salt concentrations ( Amit et al. , 2003 ) . [15066043]
  • For instance , the sequence speciﬁc DNA bending proteins IHF and Fis can relieve repression by H-NS at speciﬁc promoters ( Tippner et al. , 1994 ; van Ulsen et al. , 1996 ; Afﬂerbach et al. , 1998 ; Falconi et al. , 2001 ) . [15853876]
  • 12 C. Madrid , C. Balsalobre , J. García and A. Juárez H-NS multimerization and H-NS-dependent DNA bridging are mediated by H-NS dimers and tetramers ( Dorman , 2004 ; Stella et al. , 2005 ; Dame et al. , 2005 ) . [17116239]
  • H-NS bridging between nearby segments of DNA can generate DNA loops or hairpins ( Dame et al. , 2001 ; 2005 ) which effectively inhibit RNA polymerase access and/or passage along the DNA template , resulting in repression ( Schröder and Wagner , 2000 ; Dame et al. , 2002 ; 2005 ; Wyborn et al. , 2004 ; Gralla , 2005 ) . [20015147]
  • For instance , one of the peculiar properties of H-NS is to bridge neighbouring DNA strands , which potentially leads to repression structures ( Dame et al. , 2002 ; 2005 ) . [16238633]
  • There is increasing evidence that DNA topology in bacterial cells changes in response to environmental signals such as osmolarity , anaerobicity , temperature and nutrient status , and these alterations involve H-NS activity ( Higgins et al. 1990 ) . [7603430]
  • Under physiological conditions in vitro H-NS binds tightly to double-stranded DNA and increases the thermal stability of DNA ( Higgins et al. 1990 ) . [7603430]
  • In other cases , changes in DNA supercoiling have been proposed to mediate H-NS repression ( Hulton et al. , 1990 ; Hinton et al. , 1992 ; Owen-Hughes et al. , 1992 ) . [11123679]
  • H-NS regulatory activity depends both on its preferential interaction with intrinsically curved DNA ( Yamada et al. , 1990 ; Owen-Hughes et al. , 1992 ) and on its ability to induce bending of non-curved DNA ( Lucht et al. , 1994 ; Spurio et al. , 1997 ) . [15458420]
  • The binding sites of MlrA , OmpR , RstA , CpxR , IHF and H-NS were determined by DNase-1 footprinting assays ( Fig. 2 ; and Ogasawara et al. , 2010 ) . [20874755]
  • CRP , CpxR , CsgD , H-NS , IHF , MlrA , OmpR , and RstA on the csgD promoter ( Ogasawara et al. 2010a , b ) . [23233451]
  • Five factors ( OmpR , RstA , IHF , CpxR and H-NS ) bind to the promoter-proximal hot-spot II , while four factors ( IHF , MlrA , CpxR and H-NS ) bind to the promoter-distal hot-spot I. P1 and P2 represent the transcription initiation site P1 ( Hammar et al. , 1995 ) and P2 promoter ( Ogasawara et al. , 2007a ) , respectively . [20874755]
  • 1 NarL and NarP counteract the negative effects of Fis and IHF but not H-NS Wu et al. ( 1998 ) proposed that NarL and NarP function at pnir , in response to nitrite , by counteracting the repressive effects of upstream factors . [10972841]
  • The activity of sS is ﬁne tuned by a number of global regulators , including CRP , Lrp , IHF , H-NS and Crl ( Hengge-Aronis , 1996b ; Loewen et al. , 1998 ; Pratt and Silhavy , 1998 ) . [10594827]
  • A number of the rsdependent genes are also regulated through the action of one or several additional global regulators like CRP-cAMP , Fis , IHF , Lrp or H-NS ( see for instance Xu and Johnson 1995a , 1995b , 1995c ; Bouvier et al. 1998 ; Colland et al. 2000 ) . [12395194]
  • These include activating factors as , e.g. cAMP-CRP , H-NS and CsrA as well as repressing factors such as RcsB/A , OmpR and LrhA ( recently summarized in Prüß et al. , 2006 ) . [17537210]
  • Expression of FlhDC is tightly regulated by multiple transcription factors , including CRP , H-NS and OmpR , and hence the genes of the ﬂagellar cascade are regulated in response to many different environmental inputs ( Shin and Park , 1995 ; Sout-ourina et al. , 1999 ) . [19843224]
  • 0002-8080 G 2005 SGM Printed in Great Britain Silencing involves two sites ( Dole et al. , 2004b ) : H-NS represses transcription initiation at the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - dependent promoter by binding to an AT-rich and presumably bent upstream silencer sequence ( Schnetz , 1995 ; Singh et al. , 1995 ; Schnetz & Wang , 1996 ; Mukerji & Mahadevan , 1997 ) . [16207917]
  • Fis can also affect DNA supercoiling indirectly , because of its roles in repressing transcription of gyrA and gyrB to reduce the DNA gyrase activity ( Schneider et al. , 1999 ) , increasing topA transcription to enhance topoisomerase I activity ( WeinsteinFischer et al. , 2000 ) , and regulating the expression of other DNA-binding proteins such as H-NS , HU and CRP ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ; Gonzalez-Gil et al. , 1998 ) that also affect DNA supercoiling directly or indirectly ( Broyles & Pettijohn , 1986 ; Gomez-Gomez et al. , 1996 ; Tupper et al. , 1994 ) . [17768236]
  • For instance , combined evidence from our work and that of others shows that Fis mediates the regulation of other transcription regulators , such as GadE , CusR ( Table 2 ) , cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , H-NS and HU ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ; Gonzalez-Gil et al. , 1998 ) . [17768236]
  • However , it is possible that the change in transcription activity of PguaB in a fis background occurs as a result of altered regulation of PguaB by a transcription factor other than CRP , for example H-NS or HU ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ) or by changes in supercoiling ( Schneider et al. , 1997 ; Weinstein-Fischer et al. , 2000 ) . [18524927]
  • A similar phenomenon is observed at the Shigella flexneri virB gene , where the positive regulator VirB relieves H-NS repression , but also activates transcription directly , as well as in several other systems ( Tobe et al. , 1993 ; Murphree et al. , 1997 ; Coker et al. , 2000 ) . [11123679]
  • Although a K12DstpA strain showed similar cas gene transcript levels as a wt K12 strain ( Pul et al. , 2010 ) it can not be excluded that StpA-mediated repression of cas gene transcription takes place in the absence of H-NS . [20659289]
  • Another study showed that in this strain the transcription of cas3 , casB , casC and casD is elevated in the absence of H-NS ( Navarre et al. , 2006 ) . [20659289]
  • Finally , the effects could be indirect , for instance when overexpression of H-NS leads to the ` complete ' shut down of transcription , resulting in strongly reduced transertion mediated nucleoid expansion and , thus , compact nucle-oids ( Spurio et al. , 1992 ) . [15853876]
  • Interestingly , Fis and H-NS have both previously been shown to selectively regulate transcription by Es70 and Es38 , although by mechanisms that differ to those presented here ( reviewed in Typas et al. , 2007a ) . [18452510]
  • © 2004 Blackwell Publishing Lt Activation by Fis and repression by H-NS Fis protein has been shown to activate ribosomal RNA transcription both in vitro and in vivo ( Ross et al. , 1990 ; Schneider et al. , 2003 ) . [15686546]
  • For instance , transcription of the bgl operon is shut off in presence of H-NS ( Dole et al. , 2004 ) , and LeuO relieves this silencing ( Stratmann et al. , 2007 ) . [20132443]
  • For Regulation of rRNA transcription by H-NS and LRP 873 instance , H-NS is involved in the LRP-dependent activation of the ilvIH operon ( Levinthal et al. , 1994 ) . [16238633]
  • LRP transcription is , for instance , negatively regulated by H-NS ( Oshima et al. , 1995 ) . [16238633]
  • Model to explain H-NS-mediated Fe2 + -- Fur activation of ftnA H-NS acts as a global repressor of transcription in E. coli and many other bacteria ( Westermark et al. , 2000 ; Hommais et al. , 2001 ; Grainger et al. , 2006 ; Lucchini et al. , 2006 ; Navarre et al. , 2006 ; Stoebel et al. , 2008 ) . [20015147]
  • H-NS antagonizes the FIS-mediated activation of the E. coli rrn-operons in vivo In previous studies , the effect of H-NS as a repressor of rRNA transcription was shown under in vitro conditions ( Tippner et al. , 1994 ) . [9632265]
  • Later , in vitro and in vivo studies had shown that H-NS acts as a repressor of rRNA transcription and contributes to the rapid shutdown during the onset of stationary phase or under stress conditions ( Tippner et al. , 1994 ; Afﬂerbach et al. , 1998 ) . [16238633]
  • In conclusion , the in vitro transcription experiments indicate that H-NS represses ftnA transcription directly , as reported for other H-NS-controlled genes ( Göransson et al. , 1990 ; Tupper et al. , 1994 ) , and that Fur acts directly as an antirepressor , reversing the effect of H-NS transcriptional silencing . [20015147]
  • In contrast to its much more general role as a transcriptional-repressor or silencer ( Dorman , 2004 ; Rimsky , 2004 ) , H-NS was previously observed to activate csgD transcription by an unknown mechanism ( Fig. 8 and Gerstel et al. , 2003 ) . [17010156]
  • Because this effect is abolished in hns null cells and because the levels of H-NS increase under cold-shock conditions ( La Teana et al. , 1991 ) , this phenom-enon is adequately explained by more effective H-NS-mediated negative regulation of hchA transcription . [16796689]
  • On the other hand , it is remarkable that most of the reports about the inﬂuence of H-NS on transcription emphasize its role under limiting growth conditions , particularly at increased osmolarity , suboptimal temperature , pH variations or poor availability of carbon sources ( Arnquist et al. , 1994 ; Manna and Gowrishankar , 1994 ; O'Byrne and Dorman , 1994 ; Barth et al. , 1995 ; Yamashino et al. , 1995 ) . [9632265]
  • Although the low level of micF RNA in an hns wild-type strain prevented us from accurately comparing its half-life in the presence and absence of H-NS , it has been reported previously that H-NS does not affect the stability of micF ( Suzuki et al. , 1996 ) . [11029695]

  • Arnqvist et al. ( 1994 ) reported that H-NS prevents the functioning of E-s70 on this promoter , while E-ss is able to transcribe it , even in the presence of H-NS . [9663683]
  • OmpT-mediated proteolytic cleavage of H-NS has previously been reported ( Goldberg et al. , 1997 ) and most probably accounts for the presence of such protein . [15458420]
  • No H-NS effect was observed when cells were grown at 37 ° C ( Fig. 2C , ii ) consistent with previous observations that H-NS activity is regulated by temperature ( Ceschini et al. , 2000 ; Ono et al. , 2005 ) . [18452510]
  • H-NS , another of the histone-like proteins , is reported to be more abundant in cells grown on complex medium as compared with minimal medium ( Falconi et al. 1991 ) . [8455562]
  • In several cases , FIS has been found to regulate genes that are controlled by H-NS and CAP respectively ( Xu and Johnson , 1995b , 1995c , 1997 ; Claret and RouvieÁre-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ; GonzaÂlez-Gil et al. , 1996 , 1998 ; Afflerbach et al. , 1998 ) . [10760165]
  • Interestingly , the three genes rcsA , gadE and bglJ , respectively , encoding the three RcsB heterodimerization partners are all repressed by H-NS ( Majdalani and Gottesman , 2005 ; Stratmann et al. , 2008 ; Sayed and Foster , 2009 ) . [22295907]
  • This is consistent with observations in other H-NS-repressed operons , in which H-NS is antagonized by different positive regulators ( Forsman et al. , 1992 ; Jordi et al. , 1992 ; Tobe et al. , 1993 ; Tippner et al. , 1994 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ) . [11123679]
  • Silencing of the bgl operon by H-NS occurs under all laboratory growth conditions tested ( Prasad & Schaeﬂer , 1974 ; Reynolds et al. , 1981 ; Lopilato & Wright , 1990 ) . [16207917]
  • Similarly , the bgl operon , encoding the gene products necessary for the uptake and fermentation of aryl-b , D-glucosides is repressed ~ 100-fold by H-NS ( Higgins et al. , 1988 ; Lopilato and Wright , 1990 ; Schnetz , 1995 ; Caramel and Schnetz , 1998 ) . [15066043]
  • ( iii ) H-NS negatively regulates lysine decarboxylase CadA and cadaverine/lysine antiporter CadB , essential for lysine-dependent system ( Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ; Hommais et al. , 2001 ) . [20435136]
  • By means of sequence-speciﬁc base-pairing , DsrA enhances the stability and translation of RpoS mRNA while blocking H-NS translation and increasing hns mRNA turnover ( Lease et al. , 2004 ) . [18808381]
  • We know that DsrA not only stimulates RpoS translation , it downregulates H-NS ( Sledjeski and Gottesman , 1995 ; Lease et al. , 1998 ) , and the regions of dsrA necessary for RpoS stimulation are independent of those regulating H-NS ( Majdalani et al. , 1998 ) . [11251852]
  • In addition , H-NS negatively regulates the amount of RpoS ( Barth et al. , 1995 ; Yamashino et al. , 1995 ) . [8670904]

  • Overall , the above results suggest that hchA heat-induction relies primarily on the relief of H-NS silencing upon thermal upshift , possibly resulting from a conformational change in the DNA ( Falconi et al. , 1998 ) , and on a secondary mechanism that may involve direct or indirect activation of its EsD-dependent promoter . [16796689]

  • Several lines of evidence support this proposal : ﬁrst , bioinformatics have suggested the presence of an efﬁcient DNA helix locking mechanism by H-NS in the promoter of gadE ( Hommais et al. , 2004 ) ; Second , H-NS mediated repression has been found to be common among acquired gene clusters which is consistent with the functions of these gene clusters in conferring the survival and adaptation of bacteria in various adverse growth environments ( Oshima et al. , 2006 ) . [23874328]
  • It has been noted previously that luxAB fusions can substitute for DNA downstream of a promoter involved in repression by H-NS , because of the presence of curved DNA in the luxA gene which binds H-NS ( OwenHughes et aL , 1992 ; Forsberg et aL , 1994 ) . [8596450]

  • As binding of H-NS to areas upstream and downstream of the promoter is needed for repression , these regions were proposed to be bridged to form a loop ( Dole et al. , 2004 ) . [15853876]

[10760165]

  • This is consistent with previous analyses showing that StpA is generally subservient to H-NS in controlling gene expression , probably primarily because of its low expression in the presence of its homologue ( Sonde Ân and Uhlin , 1996 ; Zhang et al. , 1996 ; Free and Dorman , 1997 ) .   • Many genes where expression is affected by Lrp have actually been shown to be subjected to the effects , either directly or indirectly , of H-NS , e.g. papB , fin7B , ilvIH and lvsU ( Kawula and Omdorff , 1991 ; Van der Woude et al. , 1992 ; Ito et al. , 1994 ; Levinthal et al. , 1994 ) .   • However , since under laboratory growth conditions the genomic leuO gene itself is repressed by H-NS ( Klauck et al. , 1997 ; Majumder et al. , 2001 ) all LeuO regulation studies make use of plasmid encoded leuO under control of constitutive or inducible promoters . [20659289]

  • In the present study we focused on the genetic control of the structural gene for H-NS and show that hns expression , in addition to its already known cold-shock regulation ( La Teana et al. , 1991 ) , is growth-phase controlled and negatively autoregulated . [8355613]
  • The expression of leuO is likewise repressed by H-NS , and not detectable during exponential-growth ( Klauck et al. , 1997 ; Chen et al. , 2004 ) . [16207917]
  • H-NS silencing of gene expression is relieved in response to a number of environmental stimuli , including growth-phase and osmolarity ( Hulton et al. , 1990 ; Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ; Laurent-Winter et al. , 1997 ) . [10383761]
  • As leuO expression is negatively regulated by H-NS and positively by LeuO itself ( Hommais et al. , 2001 ; Chen et al. , 2005 ) , this would further amplify the activating signal for cas gene transcription . [20659289]
  • Under acidic condition , cAMP and Crp indirectly affect gadW gene expression by inhibiting the production of RpoS ( Ma et al. 2003 ) , where RpoS is also under control of H-NS ( Jung and Kim 2003 ) . [23274360]
  • The amount of H-NS within the cell is therefore likely to be under tight control , which is presumably achieved by the negative autoregulation of the hns gene ( Dersch et al. , 1993 ; Ueguchi and Mizuno , 1993 ) . [8890170]
  • The fimB gene is subject to several regulatory inputs - , suggesting that it can be exp ; essed over a range of levels in vivo : It is under positive control by LRP ( Blomfield et al. , 1993 ) , negative control by H-NS ( Dove , 1996 ; Olsen and Klemm , 1994 ) , is stimulated by a relaxation ot DNA supercoiling ( Dove and ~ o r m a n1 , 994 ) and is differentially expressed in liquid and on solid growth media ( Schwan et al. , 1992 ; 1994 ) . [8898385]

  • The gadB and gadC genes form an operon and a number of factors , including H-NS , RpoS and CRP-cAMP , are involved in the transcriptional control of gad expression ( Castanie-Cornet & Foster , 2001 ; De Biase et al. , 1999 ; Rowbury , 1997 ; Rowland et al. , 1984 ) . [14702398]

  • Among the known bacterial proteins involved in phase-depend-ent transcriptional regulation ( Azam et al. , 1999 ; Dame , 2005 ) , we have selected H-NS , StpA , LRP and FIS as potential candidates for our studies . [18177266]

  • However , in hns mutants , the PgadE-lacZ activities increased more than 10-fold to about 250 Miller units , suggesting H-NS strongly represses the expression of gadE-mdtEF under aerobic condition in the M9 glucose minimal medium . [23874328]
  • DELETION OF EvgA , YdeO , H-NS DOES NOT HAVE OBVIOUS EFFECT ON THE TRANSCRIPTION FROM INDIVIDUAL PROMOTERS UNDER ANAEROBIC CONDITION Our investigation above showed that ArcA and MnmE are the major activators responsible for the expression of gadE-mdtEF under anaerobic condition , whereas other regulators tested did not show obvious regulatory effects . [23874328]
  • ArcA ANTAGONIZES THE H-NS MEDIATED REPRESSION OF gadE-mdtEF DURING THE TRANSITION FROM AEROBIC TO ANAEROBIC GROWTH Our results above showed that the expression of gadE-mdtEF is largely repressed by the DNA silencer H-NS under aerobic conditions in M9 glucose medium , whereas under anaerobic condition in the same medium its expression is activated primarily in an ArcA dependent manner . [23874328]
  • Interestingly , under anaerobic condition , while arcA almost completely abolished transcription of gadE-mdtEF , further deletion of hns in arcA mutant restored the transcription of the full-length PgadE-lacZ , and P1 - and P3-lacZ fusions , suggesting an antagonistic effect of ArcA on the H-NS mediated repression . [23874328]
  • As shown in Figure 6B , transcription of PgadE-lacZ in arcA hns double deletion did display signiﬁcantly higher activity than that in arcA strain , suggesting that the anaerobically up-regulated gadE-mdtEF expression was through the antagonization of H-NS mediated repression by ArcA . [23874328]
  • Thus , in the present study , we ﬁrst examined whether previously identiﬁed regulators , such as EvgA , YdeO , MnmE , GadE , GadX , and H-NS , also participate in the anaerobic activation of mdtEF . [23874328]
  • Interestingly , except for mnmE , deletion of the regulators previously shown to participate in the regulation of mdtEF under aerobic condition , such as EvgA , YdeO , GadE , and GadX , caused no or only a moderate decrease ( 17 -- 40 % ) of the transcription of PgadE-lacZ , and deletion of H-NS caused a moderate increase of PgadE-lacZ activity , suggesting that these regulators are not responsible for the activation of mdtEF under anaerobic condition . [23874328]
  • Consistent with our observations at PhlyE , it has been suggested that SlyA binding to such sites remodels the local nucleoprotein structure , counteracting the effect of negative regulators such as H-NS , and clearing the way for classical transcriptional-activators such as PhoP , or as in the case of hlyE , FNR and CRP ( Ellison and Miller , 2006 ) . [17892462]
  • Discussion We began this work with the observation that a lacZ transcriptional fusion to dsrB , a small conserved gene lying between rcsA and dsrA , was negatively regulated by H-NS and positively regulated by DsrA , consistent with previous observations on other H-NS-silenced genes ( Sledjeski and Gottesman , 1995 ) . [8670904]
  • Transcriptional monocopy lacZ fusion studies showed that both operons are coexpressed during anaerobic-growth in the presence of carnitine , respond to common environmental stimuli ( like glucose and nitrate ) , and are modulated positively by the same general regulators , CRP and FNR , and negatively by H-NS . [9573142]
  • Like cai and ﬁx operons , the caiF gene appeared to be positively controlled by CRP and FNR and negatively controlled by H-NS and the NarL ( plus nitrate ) regulator . [9573142]
  • Second , pyruvate H-NS helps maintain a rapid degradation of arginine oxidase ( PoxB ) , which may be preferentially used to and glucose produce acetate when bacteria approach the stationary phase , is unlikely to play a key role under Pi-starvation Because H-NS is required for a full induction of the conditions because the expression of poxB is strictly LexA regulon in Pi-starved cells ( Dri & Moreau , 1993 ; controlled by RpoS ( Chang et at . [10439394]
  • Although a number of studies ( Tanaka et aL , 1991b ; Hinton et aL , 1992 ; Yasuzawa et aL , 1992 ; Dersch et aL , 1993 ; Ueguchi et aL , 1993 ) have previously looked at H-NS levels as a function of growth-phase by Western blotting , the results are inconclusive as to whether the protein accumulates in stationary phase or not . [8596450]
  • The intracellular level of H-NS has also been reported to increase 3-fold at the stationary phase ( Spassky et al. , 1984 ; Dersch et al. , 1993 ; Ueguchi and Mizuno , 1993 ) , although this finding has not been observed in other reports ( Hinton et al. , 1992 ; Yasuzawa et al. , 1992 ; Free and Dorman , 1995 ) . [8890170]
  • Some studies have reported an increase in H-NS levels as cells enter stationary phase ( Spassky et aL , 1984 ; Dersch et aL , 1993 ; Ueguchi et aL , 1993 ) , although this has not been detected in other reports ( Tanaka et aL , 1991b ; Hinton et aL , 1992 ; Yasuzawa etaL , 1992 ) . [8596450]
  • Surprisingly , H-NS affects both RpoS mRNA translation and RpoS turnover in logarithmic growth ; it was previously reported that there is a 10-fold increase in the RpoS synthesis rate , as well as a 10-fold increase in RpoS stability , in hns mutants ( 1 , 22 ) . [16980505]
  • After pair-wise promoter-binding assays , the increase in csgD transcription in the stationary phase was suggested to be due , at least in part , to the increase in IHF level cancelling the silencing effect of H-NS . [20466769]
  • On the other hand , a marked increase in csgD mRNA level was observed for mutants lacking CpxR and H-NS , particularly in the stationary phase ( Fig. 1b , lanes 3 and 7 ) , indicating that CpxR and H-NS are the negative regulators of the csgD promoter . [20466769]
  • Thus , the silencing of csgD by H-NS should be reduced in stationary phase because of the increase in IHF level ( see Fig. 2 ) . [20466769]
  • The present work revealed that the P2 promoter of nhaA is a stationary phase-induced promoter which is activated by sS and neither NhaR nor Na1 or H-NS is involved in this induction ; in the stationary phase , transcription from P2 increased dramatically , and this increase was eliminated in an rpoS mutant strain ( Fig. 6A ) but not in a DnhaR strain ( Fig. 6B ) . [11133959]
  • Our data support this report and demonstrate that the increased content of H-NS in stationary phase cultures is largely caused by the genetic regulation of hns transcription . [8355613]
  • Its levels are lowest when rRNA transcription is most active , and H-NS concentrations increase during entry into stationary phase . [15568992]
  • It is possible that the observed increase in ppGpp concentration during exponential-growth indicates a compensating mechanism in cells lacking functional H-NS . [9632265]
  • One might ask whether H-NS-dependent repression at the end of logarithmic growth under wild-type conditions involves a corresponding increase in the concentration of H-NS relative to exponential phase . [9632265]
  • In the exponential phase , only a few differences were observed between the wild-type strains and the mutants defective in FIS , H-NS , IHF , OmpR , cAMP , and ppGpp . [11292794]
  • In contrast , in cells expressing functional H-NS molecules a clear decrease in P1 expression is already apparent during late log phase , whereas at stationary phase the P1-directed expression is almost totally repressed . [9632265]
  • In the case of LRP and H-NS , derepression is discernible during the complete growth curve , while in the fis mutant expression of 6S RNA during exponential phase is not enhanced but rather slightly reduced . [18177266]
  • In summary , Hsp31 expression is highly sensitive to the growth temperature and H-NS plays an important role in modulating Hsp31 concentration in exponential phase cells , silencing hchA transcription more efﬁciently as the temperature decreases while allowing RNA polymerase access to its EsD - and EsS-dependent promoters in times of thermal stress . [16796689]
  • In the present paper , we report that hns transcription is under autoregulation during the logarithmic growth-phase , and that H-NS functions as a repressor for its own transcription Summary . [8437561]
  • In most of the studies , H-NS was found to be active in stationary phase ; however , some reports describe phase-speciﬁc effects during exponential-growth . [9632265]
  • In contrast , the level of H-NS and IHF increases as the cells enter the stationary phase of growth ( Spassky etai , 1984 ; Bushman efai , 1985 ; Ditto etai , 1994 ) . [7715442]
  • In this respect , it is worth mentioning that the observed auto-regulatory expression of H-NS is dependent on the growth-phase , i.e. its autoregulatory expression appears to be derepressed at stationary phase , and consequently the level of H-NS in cells appears to increase at this stage of growth . [8437561]
  • In any event , these results support the view that hns transcription depends on the growth-phase to some extend and , as a consequence , the absolute amount of H-NS in cells appears to increase at stationary phase . [8437561]
  • In summary , we conclude from these results that a measurable , although not dramatic , increase in the concentration of H-NS occurs when cells leave the exponential phase or when growth is retarded . [9632265]
  • Before cell growth ceases , at late log phase , the pre-sence of H-NS apparently enables a more efﬁcient rRNA synthesis shut-down under conditions in which the FIS concentration is still sufﬁcient to activate rRNA promoters . [9632265]
  • Our studies demonstrate that LRP binds in addition to H-NS and FIS to the upstream regulatory sequence region ( UAS ) of rRNA P1 promoters , and thus potentially contributes to the efﬁcient shutdown of rRNA synthesis , which is known to occur at the onset of stationary phase or under stress conditions . [16238633]
  • There is also in vitro evidence that the activities of H-NS ( 43 , 54 ) and of Rho ( 39 , 57 ) are sensitive to the potassium salt concentration , which is known to vary within the cell with changes in osmolarity of the growth medium ( 10 ) . [11673423]
  • Osmotic shock as well as changes from exponential to stationary growth are known specifically to decrease the K * ion concentration in the cell , and also to activate H-NS function ( Schultz and Solomon , 1962 ; Higgins etai . [7512187]
  • We note , for example , that there are 39 Fis-regulated genes or operons listed in Table 2 that have been shown to be regulated by CRP , H-NS or GadE , of which 25 exhibit Fis-regulatory effects during the late-exponential-growth-phase . [17768236]
  • A common denominator for the genes known to be regulated by H-NS ( e.g. regulation of genes at stationary growth-phase , starvation , changes in high osmolarity , low temperature shock , and altered DNA topology ) seems to be their involvement in different kinds of stress . [7512187]
  • Most of the genes belonging to the H-NS regulon are linked to the stress response or to changes in the environmental conditions such as temperature , osmolarity , growth-phase , pH , and availability of oxygen and nutrients ( 10 , 19 , 20 ) . [15795232]

  • In addition , three factors , IHF , CpxR and H-NS , bind to the same upstream region between 2188 and 2159 , designated hot-spot I. Interplay between transcription factors in binding to these two hot-spots should influence the level of csgD transcription . [20466769]

  • In addition to the competition between positive and negative factors , we found unexpected cooperation between two negative factors , CpxR and H-NS , and between two pairs of positive factors , OmpR and IHF , and RstA and IHF . [20466769]

  • This is consistent with H-NS functioning as a repressor for its own promoter , both in vivo and in vitro . [8437561]
  • Ueguchi and Mizuno ( 1993 ) have recently demonstrated that H-NS functions as a transcriptional-repressor by direct binding to the promoter region of the proVWX operon in E coli It has also been shown that , in the absence of H-NS , promo-ters may become independent of positively acting regulators such as CRP , suggesting that these regulators may act as antirepressors for H-NS ( Forsman et ai , 1992 ) . [7854117]

  • In this respect , we recently demonstrated , in vivo and in vitro , that H-NS functions as a repressor of its own transcription by directly binding to the promoter ( Uegu-chi et al. 1992 ) . [8455549]
  • Under non-cold-shock conditions , H-NS acts as a direct transcriptional-repressor of the osmotically induced proU operon ( 42 ) as well as of numerous other genes ( reviewed in reference 43 ) . [7665466]
  • This suggests H-NS functions directly as a transcriptional-repressor . [7748928]
  • H-NS , which is activated by CspA , likely acts as a cold-shock transcriptional-repressor . [7665466]
  • In contrast , Ueguchi and Mizuno ( 40 ) recently demonstrated that H-NS can selectively inhibit transcription of proU by E. coliRNA polymerase in vitro , which suggests that H-NS functions directly as a transcriptional-repressor affecting early stepsof transcription initiation . [8120010]
  • This view is supportedby the recent report of Ueguchi and Mizuno ( 40 ) , who demonstrate that H-NS can act as a specific , direct repressor ofproU transcrip tion in vitro . [8120010]
  • This delay and the lower increase of the protein level compared to that of its mRNA are not typical of the cold-shock proteins ( e.g. , CspA , DeaD and H-NS ) which are synthesized with a much shorter delay due to the efficient utilization of cold-shock mRNAs by the cold-shock-modiﬁed translational apparatus ; the accumulation of CAT activity is typical instead of non-cold-shock proteins ( e.g. , - galactosidase ) whose mRNAs are inefficiently translated during cold-shock [ 18 , 26 ] . [11278076]
  • CspA and H-NS induction patterns are consistent with the hypothesis that proteins induced early act as regulatory elements while proteins induced late perform functions directly required by the cold-shocked cell . [7665466]

  • Thus , we conclude that IHF and Fis can repress pnir in the absence of H-NS ( Table 2 ) , and that repression by H-NS can not be reversed by the action of NarL/NarP . [10972841]

  • Results Determination of new H-NS targets involved in the regulation of glutamate-dependent acid resistance As H-NS strongly represses the glutamate-dependent acid stress response , there is a very low level of survival after acid stress in the FB8 wild-type context [ 6 ] . [21034467]
  • In contrast , several genes involved in adaptation to low pH are strongly induced in a H-NS deﬁcient strain , resulting in an increased resistance to acidic stress . [11278074]
  • In parallel , H-NS decreases acid resistance by repressing genes involved in general acid stress response ( e.g. dps encoding the DNA protection during starvation protein ) or in three amino-acid decarboxylase systems , dependent on glutamate , lysine and arginine . [20435136]
  • Expression of the leuO gene is repressed by H-NS , and it is upregulated in stationary phase and under amino acid starvation conditions . [22295907]
  • First , the leuO gene itself is repressed by H-NS and is positively autoregulated ( 5 , 6 , 26 ) . [18055596]
  • However , while the relevance of LeuO and YjjQ for pathogenicity indicates that their genes are expressed under certain in vivo conditions in the host environment , both the leuO gene and the yjjQ-bglJ operon are repressed by H-NS under laboratory growth conditions ( 6 , 55 ) . [20952573]
  • However , expression of leuO and bglJ is repressed by H-NS , at least under laboratory growth conditions . [20952573]
  • YjjQ was provided plasmidically , as expression of the native yjjQ-bglJ operon is repressed by H-NS during exponential-growth under laboratory conditions ( 12 ) . [26078445]
  • Transcription of the yjjQ-bglJ operon is repressed by the global repressor H-NS ( heat-stable nucleoid structuring protein ) , and it is activated by the pleiotropic transcriptional-regulator LeuO ( 12 ) . [26078445]
  • Expression of the yjjQ gene , which is encoded in the yjjQ-bglJ operon , is repressed by the global repressor H-NS and activated by the pleiotropic transcriptional-regulator LeuO , as shown for the laboratory E. coli K-12 strain ( 12 ) . [26078445]
  • Furthermore , the yjjP gene , encoding a membrane protein of unknown function and located upstream in divergent orientation to the yjjQ-bglJ operon , is likewise repressed by H-NS . [18055596]
  • The yjjP gene located upstream of the yjjQ-bglJ operon and in a divergent orientation is likewise repressed by H-NS but is not activated by LeuO . [18055596]
  • Taken together , the data conﬁrm the regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ operon by H-NS and LeuO , and they demonstrate the repression of yjjP by H-NS . [18055596]
  • Here we show that yjjQ and bglJ are expressed as an operon , which is repressed by H-NS and activated by LeuO . [18055596]
  • RESULTS H-NS represses and LeuO activates the yjjQ-bglJ operon . [18055596]

  • Such an observation is consistent with the function of H-NS at osmotic shock or the regulation of genes expressed under stationary phase ( Higgins etai , 1988 ; Hengge-Aronis , 1993 ) , Thus H-NS may link rRNA expression to situations of rapid osmotic changes or reduced growth at stationary phase or even be effective under conditions of cold-shock ( La Teana etai , 1991 ) , Obviously , acellular process as central as the regulation of rRNA synthesis must be controlled by many different parameters and sensors to be as effective and efficient as observed . [7512187]

  • Whereas FIS is known as transcription factor responsible for growth rate-dependent activation of stable RNA expression , allowing very fast cellular growth rates and rapid change to nutritional upshifts , H-NS can be regarded as a factor that slows down rRNA transcription under limiting conditions and thus enables a better adaptation of the cell to situations when growth is very slow .   • However , H-NS can still repress the cydAB P4 promoter ( albeit weakly ) in an arcA Dfnr background 1 under anaerobic conditions ( Fig. 6 ) , and preliminary results suggest that ArcA and H-NS can simultaneously bind the ArcA-II region in vitro ( data not shown ) . [11123679]
  • More interestingly , the increased transcription of lacZ fusions in arcA hns double deletion strain than that in arcA single deletion strain was also observed in the case of individual P3 and P1 promoters , suggesting that ArcA antagonization of H-NS takes place at multiple sites in the PgadE promoter , consistent with the notion that both H-NS and ArcA can oligomerize and bind to a broad region in its regulated gene promoters ( Green and Paget , 2004 ; Dorman , 2006 ) . [23874328]
  • Although Fis and H-NS affect rrn P1 promoter activity both in vitro and in vivo , promoters lacking Fis binding sites ( or cells lacking the ﬁs gene ) are regulated normally ( 11 , 50 , 89 ) , and under most conditions ( delete `` tested '' ) , cells lacking hns still regulate rRNA transcription ( B.J.P. & R.L.G. , unpublished results ) . [15568992]
  • Thus , genetic and biochemical results ( 40,51,69 ) and thHe-NS binding studies presented here suggest that the strong but finely tuned induction of proU expression under highosmolarity growth conditions is achieved by a combination of osmotically stimulated transcription , mediated by sequences in thevicinity of the proU promoter , and osmotically relieved repression by H-NS , mediatedby the high affinity H-NS binding region at the 5 ' end of proV . [8120010]
  • Thus , in the proposed regulatory model the relative concentrations of SlyA and H-NS determine the type of nucleoprotein complex formed at PhlyE and when SlyA is dominant it inhibits binding of H-NS and , in combination with the GC-rich spacer region , maintains the topology of the promoter in a conformation that enables RNAP to begin hlyE transcription . [17892462]
  • When H-NS is dominant RNAP binding is inhibited and hlyE expression is silenced ; when SlyA is dominant H-NS binding is inhibited allowing RNAP access to the promoter facilitating hlyE transcription . [17892462]
  • When H-NS concentrations increase relative to SlyA , SlyA and RNAP binding is inhibited and hlyE transcription is silenced ( A and B ) . [17892462]
  • HdfR binds to the promoter region of the ﬂhDC operon , and its expression was negatively regulated by H-NS , suggesting that the apparent activation of ﬂhDC transcription by H-NS is mediated through the negative regulator HdfR . [10913108]
  • Upon the activation of different transcription activators in response to different environmental or physiological conditions that presage acid stresses or efﬂux of certain metabolic by-products , the activators then displace H-NS binding on the promoter , resulting in the activation of the operon . [23874328]
  • Binding of H-NS upstream of the promoter represses transcription initiation , whilst binding within the coding region is also proposed to repress transcription elongation . [16207917]
  • H-NS binds upstream of the promoter and represses transcription initiation . [15066043]
  • One possibility is that H-NS is inactive under anaerobic conditions and it disassembles from the gadE promoter , allowing ArcA which is active under this condition to-bind the promoter of gadE and initiate gene transcription . [23874328]
  • If H-NS is inactive under anaerobic condition and is disassembled from the gadE promoter , then transcription of PgadE-lacZ in arcA hns should be similar to that of arcA alone . [23874328]
  • Nevertheless , in a fis mutant the bgl promoter activity is approximately five-fold increased in the early log phase in rich medium ( unpublished results ) , and we are currently testing whether this is a direct effect of FIS-binding and whether indirect FIS-effects due to alterations of H-NS , CAP and gyrase levels in the fis mutant contribute to the activation of the bgl promoter .   • The modulatory properties of the different heteromeric complexes formed ( i.e. Hha -- H-NS , YdgT -- H-NS , Hha -- StpA , etc. ) and their formation in response to speciﬁc modulatory responses ( extreme osmolarity , changing temperature conditions or other stresses ) should be examined , as should the sets of genes regulated .   • We found that , in wild-type cells grown in LB medium at pH 7.0 or pH 5.5 , repression of hdeAB by MarA occurred only in stationary phase and was reduced in the absence of H-NS and GadE , the main regulators of hdeAB . [18083817]
  • Conversely , MarA helped H-NS repression and interfered with GadE activation of hdeAB in stationar phase . [18083817]
  • Therefore , both H-NS and GadE were involved in the increased hdeAB repression by MarA that occurred as cells enter stationary phase . [18083817]
  • MarA enhanced hdeAB repression by H-NS in stationary phase at both pH 7.0 and pH 5.5 , which indicates that MarA assists or collaborates with H-NS to repress hdeAB in stationary phase . [18083817]

[20952573]
  • In addition to being controlled by H-NS , StpA , LeuO , and BglJ-RcsB , the bgl promoter is CRP dependent and is repressed by FIS ( 4 , 48 , 52 ) ACKNOWLEDGMENTS This work was supported by a grant from the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft ( Schn371/10 -1 ) and by the Cologne Graduate School of Genetics and Functional Genomics . [20952573]
  • For example , H-NS and StpA may be involved in repair of double strand DNA breaks ,79 with the former shown to-bind to Holliday junctions in vitro .19 The possible occurrence of such events especially as part of homologous recombination occurring during rapid exponential-growth , might also contribute to the growth defect . [23661089]
  • Its activity is enhanced or diminished by other proteins including StpA , Hha and YdgT ( Cnu ) .28 ( a ) StpA is a homologue of H-NS , the two proteins sharing nearly 70 % sequence similarity .29,30 A recent in vitro study has shown that StpA can also form DNA filaments similar to those formed by H-NS and thus silence gene expression .31 Recent super-resolution microscopy showed different patterns of loca-lisation for H-NS and StpA .25 This is in curious contrast to ChIP-chip studies , which demonstrated that the genome-wide binding profile of StpA reflects that of H-NS .32 H-NS and StpA repress each other transcriptionally .29 The absence of H-NS not only abolishes StpA binding to two-thirds of its sites ,32 but also makes StpA subject to rapid degradation by the Lon protease .33 Thus , the expression level of StpA -- which contributes to its activity -- is controlled by a balance between its synthesis and degradation . [23661089]
  • Though this appears to suggest a form of molecular backup between two homologous proteins , the backup is unequal : whereas the DstpA mutant hardly affects gene expression , a Dhns mutant leads to upregulation of at least 500 genes as agreed upon by several studies .12,13,15,34 Whereas the absence of stpA does not visibly affect in vivo DNA binding of H-NS on a genomic scale , that of hns abolishes binding of StpA to about two-thirds of its wildtype binding regions .32 Though both H-NS and StpA repress each other 's transcription , leading to the up-regulation of one in the absence of the other , the degree of up-regulation conferred on StpA by the absence of H-NS may not be suficient to compensate for the lack of H-NS .30 This in part might be due to the higher susceptibility of StpA to degradation by Lon in the absence of H-NS .33 A complete backup of H-NS activity by StpA might not be desirable as there are conditions , such as a late stationary phase , in which an attenuated H-NS is favoured .36 The close relative of E. coli , Salmonella enterica Typhimurium , encodes three H-NS-like proteins . [23661089]
  • There are , however , speciﬁc differences in the properties of the two proteins ; StpA can enhance the splicing of a mutant td intron in vivo or the wild-type intron in vitro more efﬁciently than H-NS , probably due to its greater effectiveness in promoting RNA annealing and strand exchange ( 33 , 34 ) . [9006049]
  • H-NS not only represses micF but also negatively regulates stpA , and activates ompF .55 Thus , the function of StpA appears to be masked in a hns background . [11601842]
  • Polarity relief conferred by rho or nusG was unaffected in a derivative completely deﬁcient for both H-NS and StpA , although the suppression effects of YdgT or the oligomerizationdefective H-NS variants were abolished in this background . [21602341]
  • We therefore propose that it is the interruption of the linear polymeric scaffold of H-NS and StpA , caused by the recruitment of protomers of 64 or L26P into the scaffold , that is speciﬁcally required in cis for suppression of transcriptional polarity relief in the rho and nusG mutants , as depicted sche-matically in Fig. 8B and D , respectively . [21602341]

  • It has been shown that alterations , particularly increases , in the level of H-NS protein in the cell have severe effects upon gene expression and the stability of the genome ( Lejeune and Danchin , 1990 ; Barr et aL , 1992 ; Spurio etaL , 1992 ; McGovern etaL , 1994 ) , presumably through the resulting effects on nucleoid structure . [8596450]
  • In support of this explanation , inactivation of the histone-like protein H-NS , which induces negative DNA supercoiling and binds to curved DNA regions , has been shown to abrogate the requirement of the rpoS gene for expression of curli by E. coli K-12 ( Olsén et al. , 1993 ; Arnqvist et al. , 1994 ) . [11489123]
  • Despite its relatively pleiotropic effects on gene expression , regulation by H-NS is nevertheless confined to a specific subset of genes ( Bertin et aL , 1990 ; Ueguchi and Mizuno , 1993 ) , probably as a result of the ability of the protein to-bind selectively to regions of bent or curved DNA at high affinity ( Yamada et aL , 1991 ; Tanaka et aL , 1991a ; Owen-Hughes et aL , 1992 ) . [8596450]

[11029695]

[11278071]
  • CHR activity was always high because the cai operon ( responsible for the expression of carnitine metabolism ) was controlled by protein regulators such as FNR ( transcriptional-regulator under anaerobic conditions ) , catabolic repression via protein receptor ( CRP ) of AMPc , histones ( H-NS ) , and the transcriptional factor j 2 ( RpoS ) , which is expressed when the cell reaches the stationary phase of growth and inhibits carnitine metabolism ( Eichler et al. , 1996 ) . [14595781]
  • In E. coli , operons caiTABCDE and fixABCX are modulated positively by general regulators , such as the AMPc receptor protein ( CRP ) or the transcriptional-regulator responsible for anaerobic induction ( FNR ) , and negatively by the DNA-binding protein H-NS , glucose , or nitrate ( Eichler et al. , 1994a ; Unden and Trageser 1991 ) . [14595781]
  • Its expression is also dependent on the global regulatory proteins mediating catabolic repression via cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , or anaerobiosis via fumarate nitrate reduction ( FNR ) transcriptional-regulator , and the nucleoid-associated DNA-binding protein H-NS . [8631699]
  • Moreover , it is subject to global control by the same regulatory proteins which are known to modulate expression of carnitine metabolism , i.e. , the cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) receptor protein ( CRP ) which mediates the activation of catabolic operons , the transcriptional-regulator FNR that is responsible for anaerobic induction , and the DNA-binding protein H-NS ( 19 , 10 ) . [9573142]

  • The expression of gadX is activated by the alternative sigma factor RpoS during the stationary phase of growth [ 15,19,21 ] , but is repressed during the exponential phase by the nucleoid protein H-NS due to its binding to the gadX promoter or its destabilizing effect on RpoS [ 23-25 ] .   • Such extended protection is commonly observed when H-NS binds to speci ® c sites with high a nity and is probably due to co-operative binding of multiple H-NS molecules ( Atlung and Ingmer 1997 ) . [9749677]
  • These results indicate that the two nucleoid proteins , IHF and H-NS , compete with each other for binding to the respective target sequences , and in the presence of high concentrations of both proteins , only the H-NS complexes are formed because of the higher affinity of H-NS than IHF . [20466769]
  • Therefore , the displacement of one of the Fis compiexes at very high H-NS concentrations is probably the result of a conformational change owing to extensive H-NS binding , rather than a direct steric block caused by overlapping radii of the bound proteins . [7512187]
  • To investigate the relationship between H-NS and SlyA , competitive EMSA and DNase I footprinting analysis was performed in the presence of both proteins . [17827501]
  • The presence of both proteins induced a novel digest pattern at the SlyA-II site , although the two DNase I-hypersensitive sites characteristic of H-NS binding were retained , confirming the continued binding of H-NS at this site . [17827501]
  • Therefore , in the presence of a high level of H-NS , addition of a low level of SlyA did not affect the binding of H-NS at PhlyE , but when the level of SlyA was increased , a unique pattern of protection was obtained which is distinct from , yet shares some features of , the footprints made by H-NS or SlyA alone . [17892462]

  • Some of these proteins bind nonspeci ® cally to DNA , e.g. HU and H-NS , while others are site-speci ® c , e.g. FIS , integration host factor ( IHF ) , and Lrp ( Schmid 1990 ) . [9613586]
  • In contrast to HU and H-NS , FIS and IHF are site-specific binding proteins which , upon interaction with their respective recognition sites , induce a significant bend in the DNA with an estimated angle of 90 for Fis and 140 '' for IHF ( Thompson and Landy , 1988 ) . [7651128]

  • H-NS-dependent stimulation of LRP binding is independent of H-NS DNA interaction The synergism in DNA binding between H-NS and LRP could either be mediated by the formation of heteromers via direct protein -- protein interaction or involve alterations of the DNA structure , rendering it more favourable for the binding of the respective other protein . [16238633]
  • We wished to know whether the synergism between H-NS and LRP was caused by the formation of stable heteromers or alternatively resulted from a conformational distortion of the DNA , rendering it more adequate for protein interaction . [16238633]
  • It is feasible that H-NS could as well act as a bridging protein , linking LRP -- DNA complexes , which are then formed in a more speciﬁc and stable manner . [16238633]
  • The results present strong evidence that the DNA-binding protein H-NS , known to repress transcriptional activity from horizontally transferred genetic elements , is involved in downregulation of the Pcas and anti-Pcas promoters . [20132443]

  • In light of the fact that H-NS is found in a cross-section of bacterial species ( 43 ) and is part of global regulatory networks involved in virulence , metabolism , and environmental stress , yet contains no known structural peptide motifs ( such as zinc ﬁnger or helix-turn-helix motifs ) , we randomly mutagenized hns to help delineate biologically active H-NS domains . [9922259]
  • The phasing of the hyper-reactive and protected nucieotide positions is compatible with the assumption that H-NS interacts with the major groove on one side of the helix axis , thereby expanding and distorting the adjacent minor groove ( Drew and Travers , 1985 ) . [7512187]
  • In summary , the results are entirely consistent with the conclusion that H-NS , like Fis , must be a major-groove binder , and that there are more than one ( probably three ) interacting domains . [7512187]

  • These data indicate that E 70 forms an RPO even in the presence of H-NS . [16204188]

  • As in H-NS , StpA , BpH3 and HvrA , theoretical analysis suggests that the N-terminal domains of SPB , XrvA and VicH are mainly a-helical and able to adopt a coiled-coil conformation , frequently identiﬁed as the dimerization element in several transcription factors ( Lupas , 1996 ) . [9987132]

  • Interestingly , H-NS helix H2 appears to contain key residues for the interaction with its truncated derivatives : arginine at position 12 is essential for the agonistic interaction of Hha with H-NS64 ( García et al. , 2006 ) and alanine at position 16 of H-NSTEPEC for the antagonistic interaction with HNS ( Wil-liamson and Free , 2005 ) . [17116239]
  • Structural aspects of H-NS -- Hha interaction The three-dimensional structure of the Hha protein consists of four alpha-helical segments separated by loops : helix 1 ( residues 8 -- 16 ) , helix 2 ( residues 21 -- 34 ) , helix 3 ( residues 37 -- 55 ) and helix 4 ( residues 65 -- 69 ) ( Yee et al. , 2002 ) . [17116239]
  • Studies of the interaction of Hha with H-NS64 ( H-NS residues 1 -- 64 ) showed that strongly perturbed residues are located both in the surface and in the hydrophobic core of the Hha structure , suggesting that Hha undergoes conformational rearrangement after interacting with H-NS ( García et al. , 64 2005 ) . [17116239]

  • Although some H-NS functions may be isolated to particular domains , it seems likely that all portions of the protein work coordinately and in concert with each other to exert full H-NS activity . [9922259]
