  • B A Discussion In this report , we bring further evidence about the interaction of members of the H-NS and Hha families of proteins . [15458420]
  • It is apparent that interaction of H-NS with members of the Hha/YmoA family has a biological role different from the interactions reported above . [15458420]
  • Since then , interacions of other members of the family ( YmoA , YdgT ) with members of the H-NS family have also been shown [ 33,34 ] , and a mutational analysis of the Hha protein has suggested Hha consisting of a unique protein-binding domain [ 33 ] . [16143461]
  • Furthermore , this interaction appears to be wide-spread between members of both families : YmoA protein also interacts with Y. enterocolitica H-NS protein ( Nieto et al. , 2002 ) . [15458420]
  • Residues most affected by the interaction with the H-NS protein are coloured in yellow . [17116239]
  • Evidence for direct protein-protein interaction between members of the enterobacterial Hha/YmoA and H-NS families of proteins . [21602341]
  • Mutagenesis data imply that the entire Hha protein is involved in the interaction with H-NS . [15100692]
  • The relationship between members of the Hha and H-NS families is not only supported by protein -- protein interaction data . [15458420]
  • Indeed , the Hfq protein copurifies with H-NS , suggesting a specific interaction [ 26 ] and genetic data indicate that hfq mutants have phenotypes consistent with a role in modulating H-NS function [ 27 ] . [7748941]
  • One proposal , which is based on structural data from the E. coli protein , is that the interaction of the N and C termini of H-NS with DNA imposes a more stable structure on the linker , allowing it to interact with the corresponding portions of other bound H-NS mole-cules and leading to the formation of a complex , crosslinked nucleoprotein structure ( FIG. 5 ) . [15100692]
  • To clarify protein structure and function , we examined H-NS iso ¬ * Corresponding author . [9922259]
  • Overall , the results suggest that the interaction-with-DNA does not influence the quaternary structure of H-NS and that the function of this protein does not entail a direct interaction with NS ( HU ) . [3135462]
  • The possibility that protein-protein interactions modulate H-NS function remains to be fully explored . [7748941]
  • The bridging of two tracts coated with H-NS protein stems from interactions between the ﬂexible linker regions in H-NS . [15853876]
  • The H-NS protein includes two well-deﬁned domains connected by a ﬂexible linker . [17116239]
  • References Ali SS , Beckett E , Bae SJ , Navarre WW ( 2011 ) The 5.5 protein of phage T7 inhibits H-NS through interactions with the central olig-omerization domain . [22327802]
  • The proline-to-alanine substitution at position 116 has also been reported to disrupt the oligomerization of H-NS in vitro and that of a fusion protein in which H-NS replaces the missing oligomerization domain of a truncated bacteriophage λ cI repressor in vivo78 . [15100692]
  • Heterologous protein -- protein interactions The oligomerization domain of H-NS allows it to interact not only with another copy of itself , but also with heterologous polypeptides that share this domain . [15100692]
  • Based on work with regions of the H-NS protein , it has been suggested that higher-order oligomerization is a function of the central region of the protein ( residues 46 -- 90 ) 69 , which includes the flexible linker domain . [15100692]
  • Interestingly , this island -- which is thought to have been acquired horizontally -- encodes Ler , a protein antagonist of H-NS that shares the same nucleic-acid-binding domain but lacks a homologue of the H-NS oligomerization domain48 ,105 . [15100692]
  • The dimerization domain is highly conserved among members of the H-NS family of proteins , making it likely that it also facilitates heteromeric interactions . [15100692]
  • The H-NS dimerization domain deﬁnes a new fold contributing to DNA-recognition . [16980475, 14973023, 21602341]
  • The negative effects of hns mutations on bacterial motility were mainly clustered to the H-NS truncations , arguing that the conformation of this domain , rather than individual residues , is relevant to this motility phenotype . [9922259]
  • H-NS promotes looped domain formation in the bacterial chromosome . [20952573, 21602341]
  • The former involves the N-terminal domain of H-NS ( residue 2 to approximately residue 47 ) and the latter the intermediate or linker domain ( residues 58 to 84 ) , and polym-erization is achieved by the alternation of site 1-site 1 ( head-to-head ) and site 2-site 2 ( tail-to-tail ) interactions between the adjacent protomers in the scaffold ( Fig. 8A ) . [21602341]
  • Studies of mutant H-NS proteins suggest that the N-term-inal domain plays a crucial role in transcriptional repression of the proU operon and in the oligomerization process ( Ueguchi et al. , 1996 ; Williams et al. , 1996 ) . [9987132]
  • Although we lack a precise picture of the complexes formed in vivo , we speculate that Hha-like proteins , when interacting with H-NS , affect the oligomerization of H-NS by providing additional sites for interaction or by inﬂuencing the folding of the linker domain . [17116239]
  • These H-NS fragments encompass amino acids 1 to 91 and 1 to 93 and include the complete dimerization and oligomerization domain ( 14 ) and a region of H-NS ( aa 39 to 60 ) which is necessary for stabilization of StpA ( 3 , 15 , 21 ) . [16980475]
  • For repression of bgl , it was shown before that StpA complements truncated H-NS proteins comprising the N-terminal dimerization/oligomerization domain , including amino acids 1 to 91 ( or 93 ) ( 17 , 18 , 21 ) . [16980475]
  • The locations of these amino acid substitutions and their effects on various H-NS activities allowed us to construct a model of H-NS domain organization ( Fig. 4 ) . [9922259]
  • Only a few amino acids are conserved in both regions in H-NS , StpA , BpH3 and HvrA . [9987132]
  • The amino acid composition of the C-domain of StpA ( residues 91 -- 134 ) is 70 % identical to that of H-NS ( residues 91 -- 137 ) , while the C-domains of BpH3 ( residues 82 -- 123 ) and HvrA ( residues 61 -- 102 ) are both 40 % identical to that of H-NS . [9987132]
  • However , despite a low amino acid conservation in their N-terminal domain , we observed that H-NS , StpA , BpH3 and HvrA decreased , at least in part , the accumulation of ProX in an hns mutant ( Fig. 3 ) . [9987132]
  • In marked contrast , the bgl operon is not markedly activated by mutations affecting the C-terminal domain of H-NS , including the hns205 : : Tn10 allele used here ( 19 , 38 ) . [12077137]
  • García , J. , Madrid , C. , Juárez , A. , and Pons , M. ( 2006 ) New roles for key residues in helices H1 and H2 of the Escheri-chia coli H-NS N-terminal domain : H-NS dimer stabilization and Hha binding . [17116239]
  • All available data suggest that H-NS has evolved to modify its ability to modulate gene expression by interacting with proteins with at least some features of the N-terminal domain of H-NS itself . [17116239]
  • Other proteins besides the Hha/YmoA family are structurally equivalent to the H-NS N-terminal domain . [17116239]
  • Recent structural data obtained by our group ( manuscript to be submitted ) support the previous hypothesis : proteins of the Hha family bind the N-terminal domain of members of the H-NS family and are structurally equivalent to truncated H-NS proteins . [15458420]
  • Structural and functional organization of the C-terminal domain in H-NS and H-NS-like proteins The C-terminal domain is the most conserved region in H-NS-like proteins . [9987132]
  • Altogether , it seems that Hha-like proteins might have evolved to mimic the N-terminal domain of H-NS . [17116239]
  • Heteromeric complexes formed by truncated H-NS proteins ( 93 amino acid resi-dues corresponding to the N-terminal end ) and fulllength StpA may resemble structurally and functionally to complexes formed by Hha ( 72 amino acid residues , structural similarity to the N-terminal domain of H-NS ) and H-NS or StpA . [15458420]
  • A comparison of the amino acid sequences corresponding to both Hha and H-NS families suggests that Hha-like proteins may be specialized homologues of the N-terminal oligomerization domain of H-NS ( Nieto et al. , 2002 ) . [15458420]
  • Additional data supported the model ( Nieto et al. , 2002 ) : ( i ) the mutational analysis of the Hha protein suggested that Hha represents an unique protein-binding domain , ( ii ) a comparison of the amino acid sequence between members of the H-NS and Hha family of proteins suggested that Hha/YmoA are evolved to mimic the H-NS N-terminal domain and ( iii ) the interaction described between YmoA and H-NS in Y. enterocolitica suggested that such kind of protein complexes are conserved in Enterobacteriaceae . [15458420]
  • Finally , secondary structures were predicted to identify structural and/or functional domain in the H-NS protein of Y. enterocolitica using the GORIV method [ 23 ] The N-terminal domain was clearly predicted as mainly α-helical while the C-terminal domain is a probable mixed α - structure . [11278074]
  • The N-terminal domain seems to play a crucial role in the oligomerization process of H-NS and StpA . [9987132]
  • These data show that stabilization of StpA and its functional cooperation with a fragment of the N-terminal H-NS dimerization domain can be separated . [16980475]
  • It becomes StpA dependent in the presence of a fusion protein encompassing the N-terminal 37 amino acids of H-NS , which comprise the core of the dimerization domain . [16980475]
  • In addition , autorepression by StpA is enhanced in an hns : : kan mutant carrying a 70-amino-acid fusion protein , H-NSKN ( Fig. 4 ) , encompassing the 37 N-terminal amino acids of H-NS , which include the ﬁrst two alpha helices and half of the third alpha helix that form the core of the dimerization domain ( 3 , 15 ) . [16980475]
  • Structurally based alignment of the C-terminal domain of H-NS and H-NS-like protein sequences [ 2 , 8 , 16 , 28 ] . [11278074]
  • H-NS is able to oligomerize , being this property a funcion of the N-terminal domain of the protein . [15458420]
  • Isolated outside these groups , the BpH3 protein of Bordetella pertussis exhibits a low amino acid conservation with H-NS , particularly in the N-terminal domain . [9987132]
  • Moreover , we recently identiﬁed VicH ( Vibrio cholerae H-NS-like protein ) , a 135-amino-acid protein ( GenBank accession number AJ010791 ) showing a strong amino acid conservation between its C-terminal domain and that of H-NS and H-NS-like proteins ( unpublished results ) . [9987132]
  • Further according to this model , overexpressed YdgT would behave like H-NS 64 in serving to interrupt the polymeric scaffold structure by interacting with the N-terminal domain of H-NS , as shown in Fig. 8C . [21602341]
  • Structural topology of the C-terminal domain is conserved : the hydrophobic core of H-NS that holds this structure packed is built around the interactions of W109 and Y97 , Y99 , F134 and I135 . [9987132]
  • ( A ) High resolution models of dimeric H-NS based on the structure of the Escherichia coli H-NS C-terminal DNA-binding domain ( PDB : 1HNR -- residues 80 -- 136 ) ( Shindo et al. , 1995 ) and two diVerent structures of the N-terminal dimerization domain ( PDB : 1NI8 -- residues 1 -- 46 ( Escherichia coli ) ( Bloch et al. , 2003 ) and 1LR1 -- residues 1 -- 57 ( Salmonella typhimurium ) ( Esposito et al. , 2002 ) ) . [16879983]
  • NMR analysis of the N-terminal domain of Sal-monella typhimurium H-NS suggests parallel dimerization ( Esposito et al. , 2002 ) , whereas NMR analysis of the Nterminal domain of E. coli H-NS and X-ray analysis of the same domain in Vibrio cholerae H-NS indicate antiparallel dimerization ( Bloch et al. , 2003 ; Cerdan et al. , 2003 ) . [15853876]
  • Furthermore , a chimeric protein obtained by replacing the N-terminal domain of H-NS ( residues 1 -- 64 ) by the ﬁrst 60 residues of Hha partially complements some hns-induced phenotypes ( Rodríguez et al. , 2005 ) . [17116239]
  • In addition to the N-terminal domain of H-NS , the linker domain appears to be required for tetramerization and oligomerization ( Stella et al. , 2005 ) . [17116239]
  • In bold is plotted the STRIDE assignment for H-NS C-terminal domain from NMR structure and for StpA , BpH3 and HvrA C-domains from MODELLER . [9987132]
  • Tridimensional structures of the C-terminal domain of BpH3 , HvrA and StpA were calculated by homology with the NMR structure of the C-terminal domain ( 47 amino acids ) of H-NS ( Shindo et al. , 1995 ) using MODELLER ( Sali and Blundell , 1993 ) . [9987132]
  • Three-dimensional structures were obtained by satisfying spatial restraints derived from the structure of the C-terminal domain of H-NS obtained by NMR experiments ( Shindo et al. , 1995 ) . [9987132]
  • In contrast , no information is available concerning H-NS structure , except for the organization of its C-terminal domain that has been resolved by nuclear magnetic resonance ( NMR ; Shindo et al. , 1995 ) . [9987132]
  • However , except this C-terminal domain , no information is available concerning the structure of H-NS . [11278074]
  • Structural and functional organization of the N-terminal domain in H-NS and H-NS-like proteins To identify structural and/or functional domains in H-NS , StpA , BpH3 and HvrA , sequences were aligned by MULT-ALIGN and hydrophobic cluster analysis ( HCA ) methods , and secondary structures were predicted ( Fig. 4 ) . [9987132]
  • Taken together , these data reinforce the idea that similarities exist in the functional and structural organization of the N-terminal region in H-NS and H-NS-like proteins . [9987132]
  • These results are discussed in terms of H-NS domain organization and implications for biological activity . [9922259]
  • These results suggest that the hydrophobic core of the N-domain is made up of two subdomains separated by a loop ( loop 1 ) in H-NS and H-NS-like proteins ( Fig. 4 ) . [9987132]
  • Intriguingly , the N-terminal 90 amino acids of H-NS exhibit 22-29 % identity to structural proteins such as myosin , keratin and dystrophin ( fig IC ) . [7748941]
  • Dimerization of H-NS monomers requires the Wrst 64 N-terminal amino acids and the formation of larger olig-omers involves amino acids 65 -- 91 . [16879983]
  • Amino ( N ) - terminal sequences were determined for both component A ( H-NS ) and B ( HF-I ) , and compared with that of published N-terminal 5 amino acid residues of HF-I ( 15 ) . [2020545]
  • two amino acids ( Met and Ser ) were detected in the first Edman degradation cycle showing that the N-terminal Met residue is removed from only a fraction of the H-NS protein ( 1 . [8355613]
  • ( Amino acid residues in H-NS are numbered here beginning from the N-terminal methionine as 1 [ 65 ] , even though this residue is posttranslationally removed from the mature protein . [21602341]
  • The H-NS protein is 137 amino acids in length and has three structural components ( in this discussion , the amino-terminal methionine of H-NS is referred to as position 1 ) : an N-terminal domain extending up to residue 65 that contains oligomerization activity ; a car-boxy-terminal domain beginning at residue 90 that has nucleic-acid-binding activity ; and a flexible linker that connects the two16 ,56,69,70 ( FIG. 4 ) . [15100692]
  • Thus , these results suggested that the H-NS modiﬁcation site is located within the amino half of the protein , potentially near residues 18 to 26 . [9922259]
  • Among the conserved residues are most of the basic amino acids and all the aromatic residues ( i.e. three tyrosines , one phenylalanine and the single tryptophan residue , which in E. coli H-NS was found to be buried within the protein structure and sen ¬ Fig. 2 . [2494066]
  • The H-NS protein is a non-basic polypeptide consisting 01 137 amino acid residues , many 01 which are negatively or positively charged ( pi = 5.6 ) . [8355613]
  • As judged from the nucleotide sequencing data ( 24 ) , H-NS consists of 136 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular weight of 15,402 , this value being in good agreement with that for the protein purified in this study . [2126011]
  • This could account for a sensitivity of the promoter to DNA topology , which may affect such a structure , and for its recognition by H-NS , which has a preferential afﬁnity for the intrinsic DNA curvature often associated with long stretches of A and T residues . [9006049]
  • Accordingly , the intergenic common regulatory region shared by cai and ﬁx harbors putative motifs of recognition for the binding of CRP and H-NS ( 9 ) . [8631699]
  • It is noteworthy that an in vivo analysis suggests that the 13C element occurs in more than 70 % of putative rpoS-dependent promoters ( 4 ) : this observation would suggest that the 13C element might be needed to improve EsS -- promoter interaction in the bacterial cell , possibly to overcome the negative effects of DNA-binding proteins , such as H-NS , that can modulate RNA polymerase -- promoter interaction . [21398637]
  • Indeed , there is evidence that H-NS influences open complex formation rather than RNA polymerase binding [ 10 ] . [7748941]
  • The latter region is located upstream of the identiﬁed Pcas promoter , suggesting that binding of H-NS might affect RNA polymerase -- promoter interaction . [20132443]
  • It would be interesting to examine in vitro binding of H-NS to the cai ± ® x regulatory region and to study its possible interaction with the two activators and the RNA polymerase . [10564497]
  • The amino acid sequences of H-NS from various species are shown in figure I. H-NS contains a large number of charged residues although , unlike eukaryotic histones ( and most other DNA-binding proteins ) , these are predominantly acidic rather than basic ( fig 1B ) . [7748941]
  • A typical DNA-binding motif ( ie helix-loop-helix , zinc-finger ) can not be identified , and it is not known which residues of H-NS contribute to DNA-binding , although there is a stretch of positively charged resi-dues towards the C-terminus which might be involved in DNA-binding ( fig IB ) . [7748941]
  • Therefore domain A seems to be arranged in an inverted orientation relative to domains B and C. Thus , possible protein contacts between H-NS molecules and/or other components of the transcription machinery might be different for H-NS bound to domain A or B and C. Another interesting feature of our footprinting results was the partial overlap of Fis and H-NS binding sites . [7512187]
  • From the spacing of the central binding domains between the Fis and H-NS contact sites , based on the minor-groove accessibilities , a difference in the angular orientation of the protein centres with respect to the dyad helix axis of 72 '' to 108 ' can be inferred . [7512187]
  • Moreover , changing the proline at position 116 to alanine abolishes the ability of H-NS to distinguish curved from non-curved DNA , while retaining non-78 specific DNA-binding activity , and changing this residue to serine has a similar effect56 . [15100692]
  • Caret denotes residue implicated in DNA-binding in this study ; asterisks represent potential sites of H-NS modiﬁcation . [9922259]
  • This region contains two potential H-NS binding sites ( GGGTATATTG and TTGTATAAAT ) correlating with the H-NS footprint . [17881364]
  • Such cooperative binding would be achieved by formation of H-NS dimer -- dimer contacts leading to DNA -- H-NS -- DNA bridging and looping ( see two possible mechanisms in Fig. 11B ) . [20015147]
  • This binding pattern is similar to that for the rrnB P1 promoter region , where H-NS has been shown through several different footprinting techniques to interact with three DNA domains ( 52 ) . [9352908]
  • Variants of H-NS defective in one or the other of its two dimerization domains , but not those defective in DNA-binding alone , also conferred a similar suppression phenotype in rho and nusG mutants . [21602341]
  • A characteristic feature of dimeric H-NS is the presence of two DNA-binding domains that can potentially interact with two DNA duplexes simultaneously . [16879983]
  • Another model to explain H-NS inhibition of DNA looping is based on the observation that H-NS dimers have two DNA-binding domains and can bridge between DNA duplexes ( 21,43 ) . [17553830]
  • It oligomerises on the DNA and forms DNA -- protein -- DNA bridges or rod-like structures , which might be structural motifs for strong transcriptional suppression .22 -- 24 Recent evidence has suggested that the 500 binding regions of H-NS collapse together spatially into two foci ,25 which might act as the bacterial heterochroma-tin . [23661089]
  • Much remains to be discovered about the physiological significance of the H-NS complexes ; NMR structures of the Cnu and Hha proteins are available [ 9,10 ] and the structures of the N-terminal ( dimerization ) and C-terminal ( DNA-binding ) domains of H-NS are known [ 11 -- 13 ] . [23028867]
  • YdgT and Hha bear structural resemblance to , and also interact with , the N-terminal oligomerization domains of H-NS and StpA ; in this manner , YdgT and Hha are believed to modulate the DNA-binding and nucleoid-organizing properties of H-NS and StpA even though they do not bind DNA by themselves ( 23 , 30 , 33 , 38 , 42 , 55 ) . [21602341]
  • Using theoretical analysis ( e.g. secondary structure prediction and DNA-binding domain modelling ) of the amino acid sequence of H-NS , StpA ( an H-NS-like protein in E. coli ) , BpH3 and HvrA and by in vivo and in vitro experiments ( e.g. complementation of various H-NS-related phenotypes and competitive gel shift assay ) , we present evidence that these proteins belong to the same class of DNA-binding proteins . [9987132]
  • In the present paper , using an approach involving theor-etical analysis of functional and/or structural protein domains as well as in vivo and in vitro experiments , we provide evidence that , despite a low amino acid conservation , proteins such as H-NS and StpA of E. coli , BpH3 of B. pertussis and HvrA of R. capsulatus belong to the same family of structurally and functionally related DNA-binding proteins . [9987132]
  • It has been suggested that initial binding of H-NS to a preferred site is followed by lateral extension along the DNA , by oligomerization of H-NS through interactions between N-terminal domains of the protein ( Dorman et al. 1999 ; Badaut et al. 2002 ; Schroder and Wagner 2002 ) . [16204188]
  • Instead , a ﬂexible loop structure ﬂanked by a β-sheet and a short α-helix within the C-terminal half of H-NS is believed to be responsible for DNA-binding of this protein ( Shindo et al. , 1995 ; 1999 ; Schröder and Wagner , 2002 ) . [16238633]
  • H-NS-mediated Silencing of the ade Locus -- In the present work we found that mutations truncating the C-terminal DNA-binding domain of H-NS strongly induced ade gene expression . [12077137]
  • In the present study , we found that the expression of H-NS variants defective in one or the other of the oligomerization interfaces , but not in the DNA-binding domain alone , was associated with restoration of transcriptional polarity in rho and nusG mutants . [21602341]
  • For example , H-NS proteins with truncation of the C-terminal DNA-binding domain are sufﬁcient to render repression of bgl StpA dependently , indicating that StpA acts as an adapter to target H-NS mutants defective in DNA-binding to bgl ( 17 , 18 , 29 , 39 ) . [16980475]
  • In this study we employ an H-NS mutant containing an amino acid substitution within the loop region constituting the DNA-binding domain . [20132443]
  • These preliminary data suggest the existence in Y. pestis ( http://www.sanger.ac.uk/Projects/ ) of a protein which mainly differs from the H-NS protein in Y. enterocolitica by a three amino acid deletion in the linker domain located between the N-terminal region and the C-terminal DNA-binding domain in H-NS-like proteins [ 6 , 8 , 29 , 30 ] . [11278074]
  • H-NS and H-NS-like proteins constitute a large class of DNA-binding proteins As the C-terminal domain is highly conserved in the four proteins studied , we looked for similar domains in proteins of the databases . [9987132]
  • The strong amino acid conservation in the C-terminal domain of the various H-NS-like proteins prompted us to determine whether the DNA-binding properties of H-NS-related proteins were similar to those of H-NS , i.e. a preferential binding to the bla promoter region ( Lucht et al. , 1994 ; Zuber et al. , 1994 ) . [9987132]
  • This prompted us to search for H-NS-like proteins in databases using a 40 amino acid sequence extending from Lys at position 89 to Lys at position 128 in the DNA-binding domain of H-NS ( ﬁgure 4 ) . [11278074]
  • Genetic , biophysical , and structural studies have shown that the 137-amino acid H-NS protein possesses two separate dimerization interfaces , between approximately residues 2 and 47 and residues 58 and 84 , respectively , and a third C-terminal DNA-binding domain between residues 92 and 137 ( 3 , 5 , 8 , 22 , 54 , 57 , 58 ) . [21602341]
  • Based on the binding properties of an H-NS truncation containing only the C-terminal 47 amino acids of the protein ( 33 ) and analysis of H-NS mutants ( 42 ) , it has been established that the C-terminal third of H-NS encompasses the DNA-binding domain . [9922259]
  • Dimerization of the 136 amino acid H-NS protein requires the N-terminal ~ 45 amino acids , whereas the C-terminus encompasses the DNA-binding domain . [15066043]
  • H-NS H-NS consists of a dimerization ( N-terminal ) and a DNA-binding ( C-terminal ) domain connected by a ﬂexible linker ( Dorman et al. , 1999 ; Rimsky , 2004 ) . [15853876]
  • H-NS consists of an Nterminal dimerization domain and a C-terminal DNA-binding domain that are separated by a linker domain . [23873909]
  • H-NS consists of an N-terminal oligomerization domain and a C-terminal DNA-binding domain , and the ability of the protein to condense DNA and repress transcription apparently depends on its ability to oligomerize ( 19 -- 21 ) . [12077137]
  • Apparently , repression of the bgl operon is retained in such mutants because the truncated H-NS protein forms a complex with a homologous protein , StpA , which may serve as an adapter , providing a DNA-binding domain to the N-terminal oligomerization domain of H-NS ( 38 ) . [12077137]
  • In contrast , repression of bgl by StpA occurs only in the presence of the N-terminal H-NS protein domain or an H-NS-I119T mutant , i.e. , in the presence of mutant H-NS proteins defective in speciﬁc DNA-binding . [16980475]
  • That is , a carboxyl-terminally truncated form of H-NS , lacking the entire DNA-binding domain , is still able to fully repress bgl expression . [9422614]
  • It has been well documented that the DNA-binding domain is located in the C terminus of H-NS ( 33 , 42 ) . [9922259]
  • The paralog has the same DNA-binding domain as H-NS and so is assumed to bind to the same DNA sites . [17881364]
  • Studies using deletion derivatives of H-NS have assigned the DNA-binding domain to the C terminus73 . [15100692]
  • H-NS is one of the most abundant DNA-binding proteins in enterobacteria . [9987132]
  • Residues conserved in the DNA-binding domain of all proteins of the H-NS family are in boldface . [11278074]
  • Therefore , binding of H-NS to proteins lacking the linker domain ( i.e. H-NSTEPEC ) would reduce the ability of H-NS to oligo-merize and bridge DNA . [17116239]
  • Conversely , alleles encoding single amino acid substitutions in the C-terminal DNA-binding domain of H-NS resulted in signiﬁcantly reduced afﬁnity for DNA yet conferred a wild-type ﬁmA promoter inversion frequency , indicating that the mechanism of H-NS activity in modulating promoter inversion is independent of DNA-binding . [9922259]
  • Interestingly , even though residues within the DNA-binding domain of H-NS were not required for proper ﬁmA promoter ﬂipping , the entire C-terminal half of the protein was needed in some capacity , as evidenced by the mutant inversion phenotype exhibited by the H-NS truncations . [9922259]
  • We postulate that H-NS regulates inversion without binding DNA , possibly through protein-protein interactions with other mol-ecules present at the ﬁmA invertible element , and that the C-terminal domain may be important for overall structural integrity and protein stabilization . [9922259]
  • Taken together , the effects of hns mutations and deletions on ﬁmA promoter inversion and bacterial motility suggested that the H-NS C-terminal domain may have multiple functions including involvement in protein-protein interactions as well as interactions with DNA . [9922259]
  • The formation of this structure , in turn , would al!ow a more stable binding of additional H-NS mo!ecules , through long-range DNA-protein or protein-protein interactions , to the downstream site around -50 . [7934818]
  • Any cooperative interaction between the two binding proteins H-NS and LRP and the common DNA target site might in principle involve protein -- protein interaction and / or a change in the DNA conformation . [16238633]
  • HF-I copurifies with the H-NS DNA-binding protein , and it has been suggested that the two proteins may interact ( Kajitani and Ishihama . [7984093]
  • Our results suggest that the nucleoid-associated DNA-binding protein H-NS ( Hla ) plays a critical role in gene expression and in determining the structure of the genetic material . [2177526]

  • The results are consistent with the known difference of the protein domains , considered to be responsible for DNA-binding , which had been characterized for H-NS and LRP . [16238633]

  • Since the H-NS protein lacks typical DNA-binding motifs it is not yet clear how it recognizes and interaots with DNA . [8355613]
  • DNA-binding activity of altered H-NS protein . [9922259]
  • It should be noted that the mutant H-NS protein has not completely lost DNA-binding activity . [16238633]
  • These data point to a key role for this region of the protein in binding to intrinsically curved DNA , and a core DNA-binding motif , TWTGXGRXP ( where ` X ' is any amino acid ) -- which lies between residues 108 and 116 -- is highly conserved throughout the H-NS protein family16 . [15100692]
  • Summary The primary sequence of H-NS ( 136 amino acid residues , Mr = 15402 ) , an abundant Escherichia coli DNA-binding protein , has been elucidated and its quaternary structure has been investigated by proteinprotein cross-Mnking reactions . [3135462]
  • Because the derived motif depended on the assumption that high-afinity binding sites are related in sequence we used the motif to predict three potential H-NS binding sites in the ﬁs promoter from positions 150 to +1 . [17881364]
  • Nearly all of these , with the exception of the second ﬂiC peak and ﬂiD , contain the H-NS binding motif . [17881364]
  • First , highly transcribable genes contain a higher density of high afinity H-NS binding motifs . [23661089]
  • Figure 4 shows the KMnO4 reactive bases generated by RNP binding in the absence and presence of H-NS ( 228 nM ) . [16204188]
  • In addition , we demonstrate that H-NS binding exerts a specific biological function , namely to antagonize Fis activation . [7512187]
  • In vivo function of an H-NS binding motif In the absence of other data , the binding of H-NS to a site in vivo , or even the presence of a site , is not necessarily indicative of a biologically relevant role . [17881364]

  • The amino acid composition of the C-domain of StpA ( residues 91 -- 134 ) is 70 % identical to that of H-NS ( residues 91 -- 137 ) , while the C-domains of BpH3 ( residues 82 -- 123 ) and HvrA ( residues 61 -- 102 ) are both 40 % identical to that of H-NS . [9987132]
  • In the present paper , using an approach involving theor-etical analysis of functional and/or structural protein domains as well as in vivo and in vitro experiments , we provide evidence that , despite a low amino acid conservation , proteins such as H-NS and StpA of E. coli , BpH3 of B. pertussis and HvrA of R. capsulatus belong to the same family of structurally and functionally related DNA binding proteins . [9987132]
  • Plasmids containing the hfq gene , which encodes the host factor HF-1 for bacteriophage Qp , or s t p A , which encodes a protein with more than 60 % identity with the protein sequence of H-NS , can comp-lement hns mutants of a d i A ( Shi & Bennett , 1994a ) . [8704970]
  • As expected , StpA , which is a para-logue of H-NS with 58 % amino acid identity ( Zhang and Belfort , 1992 ) , shows a very similar DNA-binding characteristic as H-NS , producing the same large region of DNase I protection ( Fig. 4A , lanes 1 -- 5 ) . [20132443]
  • Recently , an E coli gene ( stpA ) has been identified whose predicted product shares 58 % sequence identity with H-NS [ 24 ] . [7748941]
  • The high sequence identity ( 58 % ) between StpA ( 15.3 kDa ) and H-NS ( 15.4 kDa ) suggested that the two proteins could have similar functions ( Zhang & Belfort 1992 ) . [10947847]
  • The 15.3-kDa StpA protein of Escherichia coli is 58 % identical to H-NS , a pleiotropic repressor and nucleoid structuring protein ( 14 , 44 ) . [16980475]
  • We found a protein , HvrA , that shows a low ( 30 % ) but signiﬁcant similarity to the whole sequence of E. coli H-NS ( Fig. 1 ) . [9987132]
  • Furthermore , its amino-terminus and amino acid composition match that of a 16 kDa DNA-binding protein ( Hla ; Laine et al. 1984 ) , demonstrating the identity of OsmZ with H-NS and Hla . [2177526]
  • Another protein , StpA , encoded by stpA , shows high sequence identity ( 58 % ) to H-NS , and it was proposed that StpA plays a role as a molecular backup of H-NS ( 30 , 39 ) . [9260955]
  • Moreover , a protein ( StpA ) showing 57 % identity with H-NS has been characterized in E. coli ( Zhang et al. , 1996 ) . [9987132]
  • This protein shows approximately 50 % identity with H-NS and with StpA , its paralogous protein in E. coli [ 16 ] . [11278074]
  • The StpA protein has 58 % amino acid identity with H-NS , and the gene was found as a multicopy suppressor of the Td2 phenotype of a splicing-de-fective phage T4 td intron mutant ( 42 , 43 ) . [9829919]
  • Cnu has 71 amino acids and 39 % amino acid identity with the Hha protein , also known to complex with H-NS to downregulate the hemolysin gene of E. coli [ 2 ] . [23028867]
  • The amino acid sequence of these proteins shows only 30 % identity with that of H-NS [ 8 ] . [11278074]
  • This protein ( ﬁgure 1 ) showed a strong homology , i.e. , approximately 85 % identity , with the amino acid sequence of H-NS . [11278074]
  • Identity and similarity scores were calculated by reference to H-NS . [9987132]
  • Madrid C , Balsalobre C , Garcıa J , Juárez A ( 2007 ) The novel Hha/YmoA family of nucleoid-associated proteins : use of structural mimicry to modulate the activity of the H-NS family of proteins . [22096603, 18545668]
  • Furthermore , this interaction appears to be wide-spread between members of both families : YmoA protein also interacts with Y. enterocolitica H-NS protein ( Nieto et al. , 2002 ) . [15458420]
  • Evidence for direct protein-protein interaction between members of the enterobacterial Hha/YmoA and H-NS families of proteins . [21602341]
  • Nieto , J.M. , Madrid , C. , Miquelay , E. , Parra , J.L. , Rodríguez , S. , and Juárez , A. ( 2002 ) Evidence for direct protein -- protein interaction between members of the enterobacterial Hha/YmoA and H-NS families of proteins . [17116239]
  • Nieto , J.M. , Madrid , C. , Miquelay , E. , Parra , J.L. , Rodríguez , S. , and Juárez , A. ( 2002 ) Evidence for direct protein -- pro ¬ tein interaction between members of the enterobacterial Hha/YmoA and H-NS families of proteins . [15458420]
  • B A Discussion In this report , we bring further evidence about the interaction of members of the H-NS and Hha families of proteins . [15458420]
  • The relationship between members of the Hha and H-NS families is not only supported by protein -- protein interaction data . [15458420]
  • Since then , interacions of other members of the family ( YmoA , YdgT ) with members of the H-NS family have also been shown [ 33,34 ] , and a mutational analysis of the Hha protein has suggested Hha consisting of a unique protein-binding domain [ 33 ] . [16143461]
  • Additional data supported the model ( Nieto et al. , 2002 ) : ( i ) the mutational analysis of the Hha protein suggested that Hha represents an unique protein-binding domain , ( ii ) a comparison of the amino acid sequence between members of the H-NS and Hha family of proteins suggested that Hha/YmoA are evolved to mimic the H-NS N-terminal domain and ( iii ) the interaction described between YmoA and H-NS in Y. enterocolitica suggested that such kind of protein complexes are conserved in Enterobacteriaceae . [15458420]
  • One of the most relevant features of proteins of the Hha / YmoA family is their ability to interact with members of the H-NS family . [15458420]
  • Other proteins besides the Hha/YmoA family are structurally equivalent to the H-NS N-terminal domain . [17116239]
  • Recent structural data obtained by our group ( manuscript to be submitted ) support the previous hypothesis : proteins of the Hha family bind the N-terminal domain of members of the H-NS family and are structurally equivalent to truncated H-NS proteins . [15458420]
  • However , the ability of H-NS to form heteromeric complexes with paralogous proteins , like StpA , and with members of the more distinct Hha protein family , might represent a mechanism for functional modulation ( see below ) . [15100692]
  • The dimerization domain is highly conserved among members of the H-NS family of proteins , making it likely that it also facilitates heteromeric interactions . [15100692]
  • In addition to interactions with closely related family members , H-NS can also form complexes with more distantly related proteins . [15100692]
  • As yet , no genes positively regulated by members of the LysR family have also been shown to be inﬂuenced by H-NS . [8932307]
  • Some transcriptional regulators bind their target sites as monomers ( e.g. , members of the AraC family and MotA from bacteriophage T4 ) ( 11 , 17 ) , or as homomultimers ( e.g. , LacI , H-NS , and the LysR family ) ( 4 , 6 , 34 , 52 ) . [21685294]
  • Interplay between H-NS and three different members of the AraC family of transcriptional activators . [8655536]
  • YdgT ( also called Cnu [ 30 ] ) and Hha belong to the H-NS family of proteins ( 33 ) , whose prototypic member H-NS participates in both regulation of transcription initiation and nucleoid structure ( reviewed in references 16 , 20 , 23 , and 59 ) . [21602341]
  • We recognize H-NS as a new and important member in the family of factors regulating rRNA synthesis . [7512187]
  • Examples of members of this family include HU , IHF , H-NS , and Fis . [1459953]
  • Fis is a member of the general family of nucleoid-associated proteins that includes HU , IHF , H-NS , LRP , and Dps ( 2 , 35 , 46 ) . [7768815]
  • For example , H. influenzae has just one gene that encodes a member of the H-NS family , and Gram-positive bacteria have none16 ,92 . [15100692]
  • YdgT and Hha belong to the H-NS and StpA family of proteins that repress a large number of genes in Gram-negative bacteria . [21602341]
  • Tendeng , C. , and Bertin , P.N. ( 2003 ) H-NS in Gram-negative bacteria : a family of multifaceted proteins . [17116239, 15458420]
  • Conclusions Proteins of the H-NS family are widespread in Gramnegative bacteria . [11278074]
  • The MvaT family protein is the functional homolog of H-NS in Pseudomonas bacteria [ 10 ] . [21350637]
  • Ko , M. , and Park , C. ( 2000 ) H-NS ± dependent regulation of flagellar synthesis is mediated by a LysR family protein . [11298291]
  • Like CfaD and VirF -- its close relatives in the AraC family -- AppY is a link in a regulatory cascade which involves the H-NS protein . [8655536]
  • Examples are regulatory proteins in the LysR family ( 34 , 48 ) , H-NS ( 29 , 61 ) , and Lrp ( 41 ) . [21685294]
  • The size of such regulatory proteins is relatively small ( LysR family , 30 kDa ; H-NS , 16 kDa ; Lrp , 15 kDa ) compared to the length of their protected DNA fragments . [21685294]
  • The bacterial H-NS protein belongs to a family of small nucle-oid-associated proteins that play an important role in the structuring of the bacterial chromosome , a function that is reminiscent of histones in higher organisms ( 6 , 29 ) . [22843842]
  • The synthesis of the Y. enterocolitica H-NS protein in the BE1410 mutant partly reversed the loss of motility on semi-solid medium ( ﬁgure 2 ) , as observed for different proteins belonging to the H-NS family [ 8 ] . [11278074]
  • IHF is a small heterodimeric protein that belongs to a class of prokaryotic histone-like proteins , together with HU , H-NS and FIS ( Schmid , 1990 ; Schmid & Johnson , 1991 ) . [9837718]
  • B himA : + hip : - f-pDRC158 : ¬ IFI'G : 1 -60 - - 4 0 * - 4 0 * - 8 0 * - 2 0 * Discussion IHF belongs to a group of histone-like proteins which , together with HU , H-NS and Fis , appear to participate in the three-dimensional organization of the bacterial chromosome ( Driica and Rouviere-Yaniv , 1987 ; Schmid , 1990 ) . [7715442]
  • H-NS and CAP both belong to a regulatory network to which FIS belongs to as well . [10760165]
  • Like H-NS it belongs to the NAPs . [25673659]


  • Edited by : Kunihiko Nishino , Osaka University , Japan Reviewed by : Yuji Morita , Aichi Gakuin University , Japan Hidetada Hirakawa , Gunma University , Japan * Correspondence : Aixin Yan , School of Biological Sciences , The University of Hong Kong , Pokfulam Road , Hong Kong Special Administrative Region , Hong Kong Island , Hong Kong , China e-mail : ayan8@hku.hk Ziqing Deng , Yue Shan , Qing Pan , Xiang Gao and Aixin Yan * School of Biological Sciences , The University of Hong Kong , Hong Kong , China Keywords : multidrug efﬂux pump , acid resistance , anaerobic adaptation , H-NS , ArcBA two-component system , antagonization INTRODUCTION Drug efﬂux constitutes an important mechanism in bacterial drug-resistance . [23874328]

  • of exogenous and endogenous hydrophobic electrophiles Involved in ﬁrst step of GMP-biosynthesis from IMP ; induced by low pH during anaerobic growth Catalyzes the irreversible NADPH-dependent deamination of GMP to IMP ; functions in the conversion of nucleobase , nucleoside , and nucleotide derivatives of G-to-A nucleotides and in maintaining the intracellular balance of A and G nucleotides DNA gyrase negatively supercoils closed circular double-stranded DNA in an ATP-dependent manner and also catalyzes the interconversion of other topological isomers of double-stranded DNA rings , including catenanes and knotted rings See GyrA Uses temp-induced exposure of structured hydrophobic domains to capture and stabilize early unfolding protein intermediates under severe thermal stress ; rapidly releases them once stress has abated and is induced by heat shock Induced by low pH during anaerobic growth and at the stationary phase Periplasmic protein that may be involved in acid resistance ; AccC catalyzes the carboxylation of the carrier protein and then the transcarboxylase transfers the carboxyl group to form malonyl-CoA See AccA ; induced by high pH during anaerobic growth 4.57 / 22,029 4.74 / 18,338 ( 4 -- 5 ) 5.01 / 18,459 ( 4 -- 5 ) 4.78 / 15,809 ( 4 -- 5 ) See AccA See AccA 6.65 / 49,320.74 7.58 / 33,321.89 P24182 P0A9Q5 AccC AccD 179 179 Involved in glyoxylate-bypass ; activated by phosphorylation ( on histidine ) and inhibited by phosphoenolpyruvate ( PEP ) , 3-phosphoglycerate , and succinate ; induced by pH change ; increases in the physiological short-term adaptation to glucose limitation The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex contains multiple copies of three enzymatic components : pyruvate dehydrogenase ( E1 ) , dihydrolipoamide acetyltransferase ( E2 ) , and lipoamide dehydrogenase ( E3 ) ; catalyzes the overall conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and CO2 ; increases during aerobic growth and after benzoic acid treatment See AceE ; increases during aerobic growth , during the low temp at 10 ° C , and after benzoic acid treatment Involved in the activation of acetate to acetyl-CoA and the secretion of acetate ; involved in the synthesis of most of the ATP formed catabolically during anaerobic growth ; induced by low pH during anaerobic growth Aconitate hydratases ( AcnA and AcnB ) serve as a protective buffer against the basal level of oxidative stress that accompanies aerobic growth by acting as a sink for reactive-oxygen-species and by modulating translation of the sodA transcript ; AcnA enhances the stability of the sodA transcript , whereas AcnB lowers its stability ; it is induced by iron and oxidative stress and may have an ironresponsive regulatory function See AcnA AceA 27 , 179 , 287 , 311 5.16 / 47,521.57 P0A9G6 5.19 / 44,130 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.12 / 44,130 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.01 / 33,761 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 4.99 / 33,624 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.01 / 51,702 ( 5 -- 6 ) AceE 5.40 / 99,289 5.46 / 99,537.29 P0AFG8 Pyruvate dehydrogenase E1 component 179 , 228 , 270 , 294 , 321 5.39 / 94,195 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) AceF Dihydrolipoyllysine residue acetyltransferase component of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex Acetate kinase P06959 133 , 179 , 228 , 270 , 294 , 321 5.01 / 77,450 5.09 / 65,964.87 5.09 / 78,105 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) AckA 5.84 / 44,001 5.85 / 43,290.45 P0A6A3 179 , 228 , 294 , 287 , 321 , 323 5.79 / 41,417 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 5.72 / 31,846 ( 5 -- 6 ) 5.59 / 97,516.00 Aconitate hydratase 1 P25516 AcnA 151 , 278 AcnB 151 , 179 , 278 , 287 , 321 Aconitate hydratase 2 P36683 5.30 / 95,000 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 5.24 / 75,907 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.24 / 93,498.11 Continued on facing pag TABLE 2 -- Continued pI/MW Descriptionb Protein function and expressione Experimentald Theoreticalc AcpP P0A6A8 Acyl carrier protein 3.98 / 8,508.33 A carrier of the growing fatty acid chain in fatty-acid-biosynthesis ; segments of DNA on both sides of a bend centered around position 150 ; the hns mutant exhibit derepression not only of csgBA , hdeAB , mcc , and osmY but also of the expression of at least 22 maturation of iron-sulfur cluster-containing proteins ; seems to help targeting proteins to be folded toward HscA Redox regulated molecular chaperone ; protects both thermally unfolding and proteins bound to the IbpAB complex are more efﬁciently refolded and reactivated by the ATP-dependent chaperone systems ClpB and DnaK/DnaJ/GrpE ; its activity is ATP independent ; IbpAB increase in overexpression of heterologous proteins and biopolymers See IbpA ; decreases during phosphate limitation early Inhibition of this enzyme by phosphorylation regulates the branch point between the [14996792]

  • It also inhibits H-NS translation by sharply increasing hns mRNA turnover ( 40 , 44 ) and thereby curtails H-NS-me-diated transcriptional silencing . [17557827]
  • Panels A [ H-NS ] and B [ StpA ] : a , W3110 , A-type lineage ; b , BSN27 , hns disruptant ; c , BSN28 , stpA disruptant ; d , ÿ ÿ BSN29 , hns stpA double mutant . [10947847]
  • ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS We thank Erhard Bremer for generously providing strain PD32 ( hns-206 ) and plasmid pPD3 for overproduction of H-NS . [8655536]
  • There is increasing evidence that DNA topology in bacterial cells changes in response to environmental signals such as osmolarity , anaerobicity , temperature and nutrient status , and these alterations involve H-NS activity ( Higgins et al. 1990 ) . [7603430]
  • Recently the phenotypically cryptic csgA gene has been shown to be transcriptionally activated by mutations affecting H-NS ( A , Oisen , A , Arnqvist and S. Normark , unpublished ) , suggesting that the activation of csgA in HBIOI and many other E. co / ; strains may involve local changes in DNA topology -LCB- Hulton et al. , 1990 ) . [1357528]
  • This promoter is controlled by a number of global regulators such as CRP ( Yokota and Gots , 1970 ; Silverman and Simon , 1974 ) , heat shock proteins DnaK , DnaJ and GrpE ( Shi et al. , 1992 ) and H-NS ( Bertin et al. , 1994 ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Yanagihara et al. , 1999 ) , as well as by several environmental signals such as temperature control ( Qualding and Stocker , 1962 ; Adler and Templeton , 1967 ) , high concentrations of inorganic salts , carbohydrates or alcohols ( Li et al. , 1993 ; Shi et al. , 1993 ) , growth phase ( Nishimura and Hirota , 1989 ) , DNA supercoiling ( Li et al. , 1993 ; Shi et al. , 1993 ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Das et al. , 1998 ) , phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol-synthesis ( Shi et al. , 1993 ; Mizushima et al. , 1995 ) , cell-cycle control ( Morgan et al. , 1995 ; Prüß and Matsumura , 1996 ; Mizushima et al. , 1997 ) and quorum-sensing ( Sperandio et al. , 2002 ) . [11929534]
  • Fis can also affect DNA supercoiling indirectly , because of its roles in repressing transcription of gyrA and gyrB to reduce the DNA gyrase activity ( Schneider et al. , 1999 ) , increasing topA transcription to enhance topoisomerase I activity ( WeinsteinFischer et al. , 2000 ) , and regulating the expression of other DNA-binding proteins such as H-NS , HU and CRP ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ; Gonzalez-Gil et al. , 1998 ) that also affect DNA supercoiling directly or indirectly ( Broyles & Pettijohn , 1986 ; Gomez-Gomez et al. , 1996 ; Tupper et al. , 1994 ) . [17768236]
  • Several DNA-binding proteins , including H-NS ( Suzuki et al. , 1996 ) , HU ( Painbeni et al. , 1997 ) , Lrp ( Ferrario et al. , 1995 ) , Rob ( Ariza et al. , 1995 ) , SoxS ( Chou et al. , 1993 ) and MarA ( Cohen et al. , 1988 ; Jair et al. , 1995 ) , are known to regulate micF promoter activity and , consequently , modulate ompF mRNA translation . [11029695]
  • In fact , control by Lrp often involves H-NS protein , e.g ompF and ompC ( Graeme-Cook et al. 1989 ; Ernsting et al. 1992 ) , fimB ( Kawula and Orndorff 1991 ; Blomfield et al. 1993 ) , papB ( van der Woude et al. 1992 ) , ilvIH ( Levinthal et al. 1994 ) , and lysU ( Ito et al. 1994 ) . [7603430]
  • This hypothesis is consistent with findings regarding H-NS control of the transcription of several other operons , which are also under Lrp control : ompFand ompC ( Graeme-Cook et al. 1989 ; Ernsting et al. 1992 ) , fimB ( Kawula and Orndorff 1991 ; Blomfield et al. 1993 ) , and papB ( van der Woude et al. 1992 ) . [8152423]
  • We also engineered the global regulator H-NS to control biofilm-formation via prophage excision and cell-death ( Hong et al. , 2010 ) . [21059164]
  • By discovering BdcA and creating the E50V and E50Q variants , we have also obtained important new tools that along with H-NS K57N ( evolved to decrease biofilm-formation through cell lysis by inducing cryptic prophage Rac ) ( Hong et al. , 2010 ) , SdiA 1E11 ( evolved to decrease biofilm-formation by increasing indole concentrations ) ( Lee et al. , 2009 ) , and SdiA SD10 ( evolved to increase biofilm with the addition of homoserine lactone signals ) ( Lee et al. , 2009 ) , allow the control of biofilm-formation for various applications . [21059164]
  • 2010 SGM Printed in Great Britain In concert with the complex mode of regulation for biofilm-formation , the expression of csgD has been proposed to be under the control of various stress-sensing regulatory proteins such as OmpR ( Romling et al. , 1998 ; Vidal et al. , 1998 ; Prigent-Combaret et al. , 1999 , 2000 , 2001 ; Gerstel & Romling , 2001 ; Gerstel et al. , 2003 ) , CpxR ( PrigentCombaret et al. , 2001 ; Jubelin et al. , 2005 ) , Crl ( Bougdour et al. , 2004 ; Robbe-Saule et al. , 2006 ) , CRP ( Zheng et al. , 2004 ) , H-NS ( Arnqvist et al. , 1994 ; Gerstel et al. , 2003 ; Olsen et al. , 1993 ) , IHF ( Gerstel et al. , 2003 ; Gerstel & Romling , 2001 ) , MlrA ( Brown et al. , 2001 ) and RcsB ( Ferrieres & Clarke , 2003 ; Vianney et al. , 2005 ) . [20466769]
  • Furthermore , a number of transcription factors are involved in the regulation of the csgD promoter , including CpxR ( Jubelin et al. , 2005 ) , Crl ( Bougdour et al. , 2004 ) , H-NS ( Gerstel et al. , 2003 ) , IHF ( Gerstel et al. , 2003 , 2006 ) , OmpR ( Vidal et al. , 1998 ; Gerstel et al. , 2003 , 2006 ) , RstA ( Ogasawara et al. , 2007a ) , MlrA ( Brown et al. , 2001 ) , RcsB ( Ferrieres & Clarke , 2003 ; Vianney et al. , 2005 ) and CRP ( Zheng et al. , 2004 ) . [20874755]
  • The latter circuit is also the most complex because apart from GadX and GadW , it also involves the global regulators H-NS and CRP , which act as transcriptional repressors , and RpoS , which positively affects gadA and gadBC transcription ( De Biase et al. , 1999 ; Castanie-Cornet and Foster , 2001 ; Hommais et al. , 2001 ; Tramonti et al. , 2002 ; Giangrossi et al. , 2005 ; Weber et al. , 2005 ) . [18808381]
  • In E. coli , several global regulators such as H-NS ( Bertin et al. , 1994 ) , OmpR ( Shin & Park , 1995 ) , CRP-cAMP ( Soutourina et al. , 1999 ) , LrhA ( Lehnen et al. , 2002 ) and RcsAB ( Francez-Charlot et al. , 2003 ) are directly involved in the complex genetic regulatory hierarchy that assures ordered assembly of ﬂagellar components . [20528937]
  • Model to explain H-NS-mediated Fe2 + -- Fur activation of ftnA H-NS acts as a global repressor of transcription in E. coli and many other bacteria ( Westermark et al. , 2000 ; Hommais et al. , 2001 ; Grainger et al. , 2006 ; Lucchini et al. , 2006 ; Navarre et al. , 2006 ; Stoebel et al. , 2008 ) . [20015147]
  • Recently , we reported that deletion of hns ( encoding the global regulator H-NS ) abolished eDNA production in E. coli ( Sanchez-Torres et al. 2010 ) . [21181144]
  • ( iii ) H-NS negatively regulates lysine decarboxylase CadA and cadaverine/lysine antiporter CadB , essential for lysine-dependent system ( Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ; Hommais et al. , 2001 ) . [20435136]
  • Overproduction or an altered regulation of H-NS has been reported to exert some deleterious effects on cell-physiology ( Spurio et al. , 1992 ) , including swarm migration ( Hinton et al. , 1992 ) . [11031114]
  • H-NS negatively regulates RpoS translation ( Barth et al. , 1995 ; Yamashino et al. , 1995 ) . [8670904]
  • Indirect action could be via transcriptional regulation of a gene involved in RpoS translational regulation , as suggested by Yamashino and colleagues for the action of H-NS on RpoS ( Yamashino et al. , 1995 ) . [8670904]
  • More recently , H-NS had aiso been demonstrated to be a transcriptional repressor involved in the regulation of a number of apparently unrelated genes ( BertJn et ai , 1990 ; Yamada etai . [7512187]
  • H-NS is involved in numerous cellular-processes , including replication ( Katayama et al. , 1996 ) , recombination ( Goshima et al. , 1994 ) and transcriptional regulation of a large number of genes ( Ussery et al. , 1994 ; Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ) . [11123679]
  • Among the known bacterial proteins involved in phase-depend-ent transcriptional regulation ( Azam et al. , 1999 ; Dame , 2005 ) , we have selected H-NS , StpA , LRP and FIS as potential candidates for our studies . [18177266]
  • Among a set of more than 12 characterized proteins , FIS , H-NS , IHF and LRP have been recognized as more speciﬁc regulators , acting as transcriptional activators or repressors for numerous genes ( Azam and Ishihama , 1999 ; Dame et al. , 2005 ) . [16238633]
  • Intriguing results on the possible function of H-NS were obtained recently in genetic studies of drdX ( G6ransson et al. 1990 ) , a regulatory locus involved in the thermoregulation of a determinant of pilus adhesion , and also in genetic studies on osmZ , which is a mutation that causes altered osmoregulation of the proU operon ( Higgins et al. 1988 ; Hulton et al. 1990 ; May et al. 1990 ) . [8455549]
  • Moreover , a possible role of H-NS in many other biological-processes such as replication , recombination and transposition has also been suggested ( Ussery et al. , 1994 ) . [9987132]
  • In view of new ﬁndings related to the role of H-NS in silencing foreign DNA ( Lucchini et al. , 2006 ; Navarre et al. , 2006 ) , it would be interesting to determine whether Hha is also involved in such processes . [17116239]
  • LeuO is another Leu-sensing global regulator that controls * 140 targets , of which most are involved in anti-silencing against the H-NS silencer ( Shimada et al. , 2011 ) . [2162465]
  • Recent data indicate that LeuO is involved in regulating transcription of many genes , often as an H-NS antagonist ( Stoebel et al. , 2008 ; Shimada et al. , 2009 ) . [20659289]
  • For Regulation of rRNA-transcription by H-NS and LRP 873 instance , H-NS is involved in the LRP-dependent activation of the ilvIH operon ( Levinthal et al. , 1994 ) . [16238633]

  • Discussion H-NS regulates directly and indirectly the RcsB-P/GadE complex , that is located at the centre of the acid resistance network as well as control of motility ( Figure 3 ) . [21034467]
  • Expression of these components is under the control of a complex network of transcription factors , including GadE , GadX , GadW , EvgA , YdeO , and H-NS [ 1 ] . [25375160]
  • To find further H-NS-dependent intermediary actors of glutamate-dependent acid resistance , several of the H-NS induced targets , identified in a previous transcriptome analysis [ 1 ] and related either to acid stress resistance or to information pathways , were deleted in an hns-deficient strain . [21034467]
  • Identification of the target genes for major regulators To decipher the regulatory hierarchy in acid stress resistance involving several new H-NS controlled regulators , the mRNA level of target genes was compared between wild-type and hns , hns rcsB , hns gadE , hns hdfR , hns adiY mutant strains , using real-time quantitative RT-PCR ( Table 4 ) . [21034467]
  • To identify targets of the RcsBeGadE complex that are involved in acid stress resistance , the mRNA level of genes previously identiﬁed as H-NS targets were compared between wild-type and hns , hns rcsB and hns gadE mutant strains using real-time quantitative RT-PCR ( Table 5 ) . [20435136]
  • Indeed , the EvgA-YdeO regulatory pathway plays a secondary modulator role in the glutamate-dependent acid stress response , in comparison to H-NS . [21034467]
  • In particular , the putative regulator , YhiX , plays a central role in the H-NS control of genes required in the glutamate-dependent acid stress response . [11298273]
  • In this regulatory process H-NS represses the expression of gadE ( encoding the central activator of the glutamate-dependent acid resistance pathway ) both in a direct and an indirect way , via EvgA , YdeO , GadX and GadW [ 1,7,8 ] , while it decreases rcsD expression , essential to the phosphorylation of RcsB ( the capsular synthesis regulator component ) required for the formation of the regulatory complex with GadE [ 6 ] . [21034467]
  • ( i ) H-NS represses the gadE gene encoding the central activator of the glutamate-dependent acid resistance pathway . [20435136]
  • Conclusions : H-NS lies near the top of the hierarchy orchestrating acid response centred on RcsB-P/GadE regulatory complex , the general direct regulator of glutamate - , arginine - and lysine-dependent acid resistance pathways . [21034467]
  • Finally , we found that in addition to H-NS and RcsB , a third regulator , HdfR , inversely controls glutamate-dependent acid resistance pathway and motility . [21034467]
  • Thus , our results argue that CRP , not H-NS , is a master regulator of glutamate-dependent acid resistance . [12446650]
  • Decrypting the H-NS-dependent regulatory Abstract Background : H-NS regulates the acid stress resistance . [21034467]
  • ( ii ) H-NS also represses arginine decarboxylase AdiA and arginine : agmatine antiporter AdiC ( YjdE ) , essential for arginine-dependent acid resistance . [20435136]
  • The gadA/BC genes , activated in response to acid stress and in stationary phase cells , are subjected to complex circuits of regulation involving 70 , S , cAMP receptor protein , H-NS , EvgAS , TorRS , GadE , GadX , GadW , and YdeO . [15795232]
  • In parallel , H-NS decreases acid resistance by repressing genes involved in general acid stress response ( e.g. dps encoding the DNA-protection during starvation protein ) or in three amino-acid decarboxylase systems , dependent on glutamate , lysine and arginine . [20435136]
  • Determination of H-NS targets involved in arginine and / or lysine-dependent acid resistance We wondered whether the new genes identified as H-NS-controlled , but unrelated to regulation by the RcsB-P / GadE complex , also play a role in the arginine and lysine-dependent acid resistance pathways . [21034467]
  • This suggests a role of CadC regulator in the H-NS regulation of the lysine-dependent acid stress resistance and a role of AdiY regulator in the arginine - and glutamate-dependent pathways . [21034467]
  • Quantitative RT-PCR analysis of H-NS targets involved in acid stress resistance . [20435136]
  • Results Determination of new H-NS targets involved in the regulation of glutamate-dependent acid resistance As H-NS strongly represses the glutamate-dependent acid stress response , there is a very low level of survival after acid stress in the FB8 wild-type context [ 6 ] . [21034467]
  • The new characterized H-NS targets , CadC and AdiY , have no effect on motility ( data not shown ) and are involved in the H-NS-dependent regulation of lysine and arginine-dependent response to acid stress , respectively ( Table 3 ) . [21034467]

  • Our results indicate that relief of inhibition by H-NS is involved in both stationary-phase-associated and hyperosmotic induction of rpoS . [7768855]

[20015147]
  • Histone-like proteins , such as IHF , H-NS , HU , and Fis , play a major role in modifying DNA conformation , changing the access of certain regulators and/or RNA polymerase to promoters ( 2 , 10 ) . [10850997]

  • We have concentrated on a selection of proteins ( FIS , H-NS , LRP and StpA ) whose regulatory properties are either typically linked to changes in the environment and the growth behavior of the cells or to stress adaptation and nutritional quality . [18177266]
  • Since the H-NS , HU , IHF and Fis proteins participate in a wide variety of cellular-processes , careful control of their intracellular amount at a given time during the bacterial growth cycle is obviously of great importance for cell-physiology . [8355613]
  • Expression of Dps is known to be regulated by OxyR , in response-to-oxidative-stress ( 2 ) , and three nucleoid proteins , IHF , Fis , and H-NS , in response to growth phase ( 2 , 8 ) . [21239586]
  • Because H-NS often acts in combination with other nucleoid-associated proteins ( NAPs ) we have also analy-sed the binding of related regulatory proteins , such as StpA , LRP and FIS ( Luijsterburg et al. , 2006 ; Dorman , 2009 ) . [20132443]
  • It is becoming increasingly evident that nucleoid-associated proteins such as H-NS may play important roles as participants in transcriptional regulatory mechanisms and as modulators and/or architectural components . [9829919]
  • On this view FIS , and possibly also CRP , act to ﬁne tune a fundamental mode of transcriptional regulation , not only by their direct effects on DNA topology but also from the indirect effects of their transcriptional-control of other nucleoid-associated proteins , such as HU and H-NS [ 3 , 4 ] , which also act as determinants of chromosomal structure . [11278071]
  • The two proteins FIS and H-NS have previously been described to act as antagonistic transcription factors for rRNA-synthesis . [16238633]
  • A whole battery of regulatory mechanisms is known to control rRNA-transcription , including the involvement of two small regulatory proteins , FIS and H-NS ( Gralla , 2005 ) . [16238633]
  • Expression of functional Cas proteins therefore requires anti-silencing mechanisms abrogating H-NS repression in order to become effective . [20132443]
  • They include several known proteins , namely , NusA , IF2 , polynucle-otide phosphorylase , RecA , H-NS , and the a subunit of DNA gyrase . [8631696]
  • Some inducible processes , including pH-regulated ones , which show a DNA gyrase requirement , involve both integration host factor , IHF , which is hrmA/hzmD encoded , and H-NS ( Stim and Bennett 1993 ) . [8588889]
  • In addition to its role in structuring the chromosome , H-NS is also known to inﬂu-ence several cellular functions , such as defense against foreign DNA , virulence , general stress response , genome stability , and metabolism ( 1 , 2 , 9 , 17 , 26 ) . [22843842]
  • Whether H-NS is also involved in this process ( e.g. by binding to AT-rich foreign DNA , marking it as proto-spacer for integration within the CRISPR array ) remains to be examined . [20132443]
  • It is interesting to note that both integration host factor and H-NS , the product of the hns gene , seems to be involved in interactions with curves or bends in DNA , and the role and regulation of this aspect of DNA structure are areas of broad current interest . [8383109]
  • The observation that down-regulation also fails to occur in an hns mutant supports the hypothesis that H-NS is solely ( or at least primarily ) responsible for the regulation of its own promoter in response to changing rates of DNA-synthesis . [8596450]
  • Furthermore , the data support the conclusion that LeuO , whose expression is likewise repressed by H-NS and which is a virulence factor in Salmonella enterica , is a master regulator that among other loci , also controls the yjjQ-bglJ operon and thus indirectly the presumptive targets of YjjQ and BglJ . [18055596]
  • LeuO , a regulator that is conserved in Enterobacteriaceae , is of pleiotropic function which includes virulence control in Salmonella enterica , and it is considered an antagonist of the global repressor H-NS ( 13 , 15 , 56 ) . [26078445]
  • Expression profiling of wild-type and H-NS-deficient strains H-NS has been described as a transcriptional regulator ( Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ) . [11298273]
  • H-NS thus appears to function as a global DNA-binding transcriptional regulator ( 7 ) . [8244952]
  • H-NS binds DNA , especially A+T - rich regions including promoter regions or horizontally acquired DNA and acts as a global transcriptional repressor [ 4 ] . [21350637]
  • H-NS binds the chiA promoter region with high affinity The global transcriptional repressor H-NS has a negative effect on expression of a number of genes , in particular those regulated by different environmental factors ( e.g. temperature , pH or osmolarity ; Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ) . [10760150]
  • The major role of H-NS is as a global transcriptional repressor for a large number of genes ( for a review , see reference 5 ) . [16980505]
  • The results of recent extensive genetic studies on H-NS clearly support the hypothesis that H-NS may function as a global trans-acting transcriptional regulator ( see Introduction ) . [8437561]
  • 3.3 A molecular backup between two global transcriptional repressors The use of homologous proteins ( H-NS and StpA ) acting together to silence expensive genes might confer robustness in the event of a mutation adversely affecting the function of either . [23661089]
  • However , H-NS also acts as a positive regulator for lrp ( 33 ) and ﬂagellum biosynthesis genes ( 3 ) . [9352908]
  • As noted above , IHF acts as a positive regulator while H-NS is a potent repressor . [20466769]
  • In the virulence regulatory system in S. ﬂexneri , H-NS probably acts only as a repressor for the VirF-activated transcription of VirB , which in turn activates expression of several operons encoding functions required for virulence ( 33 , 34 ) . [8655536]
  • H-NS , which is activated by CspA , likely acts as a cold shock transcriptional repressor . [7665466]
  • In addition to its function as a transcriptional activator , ArcA modulates the activities of the aerobic repressor ( H-NS ) and the anaerobic repressor ( Fnr ) . [11123679]
  • In addition , H-NS is a repressor of virB ( Tobe etal . [8704970]

  • Osmotic upshift Cold shock Discussion Participation of H-NS in growth rate regulation One of the hallmarks in the regulation of rRNA-synthesis , apart from stringent control , is growth rate regulation . [9632265]
  • 346 Moreover , the data indicate that H-NS is involved in both the growth phase-associated and osmotic regulation of rpoS expression . [7768855]
  • Although the regulation of rRNA-synthesis is clearly related to the growth phase-dependent expression of the activator FIS , a similar relationship to the concentration of H-NS is less clear . [9632265]

  • Clearly , DsrA could be important for coordinate regulation of these pathways and those controlled by H-NS and RpoS , thereby acting as a global orchestrator of a broad sweep of biological functions . [9770507]
  • Since RpoS and H-NS play an important role in globally regulating genes in response to changing environments , it is not surprising that AI-2-related QS networks utilize their uptake regulators ( e.g. , LsrR and LuxP ) , together with DsrA , in a hierarchical modality for mediating prompt responses to environmental stimuli and extracellular stresses . [17557827]
  • H-NS plays a pleiotropic role in bacterial response to environmental stimuli such as temperature , osmolarity , pH , and starvation ( 17 ) . [20211899]
  • H-NS regulates bacterial response to osmolarity and other stresses . [20211899]
  • H-NS is a major component of chromatin in enteric bacteria which plays a structural role in organizing the chromosome and inﬂuences DNA rearrangements as well as the expression of many genes involved in the response to environmental signals , such as osmolarity , pH , oxygen availability , nutrient status , and temperature ( reviewed in references 18 and 51 ) . [8932307]
  • H-NS regulates many stress response genes by acting as a major component of chromatin and by responding to changes in osmolarity ( 5 , 21 ) . [16997959]

  • Conclusion In E. coli , the control of acid stress resistance is achieved by the concerted efforts of multiple regulators and overlapping systems , most of the genes directly involved in acid resistance being both controlled by RcsB-P/GadE complex and by at least one other regulator such as H-NS , HdfR , CadC or AdiY .   • This suggests that overexpression of either GadX or GadE alone , in an FB8 genetic background , is not sufﬁcient to induce expression of genes involved in the bacterial response to low pH when cells are grown at neutral pH. Overexpression of gadX signiﬁcantly induced the expression of 48 genes of the H-NS regulon ( Table 3a ) . [14702398]
  • In contrast , several genes involved in adaptation to low pH are strongly induced in a H-NS deﬁcient strain , resulting in an increased resistance to acidic stress . [11278074]
  • In particular , H-NS was shown , unlike StpA , to control several genes involved in bacterial motility and low pH resistance . [11278074]
  • Several environmentally regulated genes are under the negative control of H-NS , including rpoS encoding another global regulator , the stationary-phase sigma factor RpoS ( 2 , 35 ) . [22843842]
  • According to our results , the master regulators H-NS and RpoS are hierarchically involved in the transcriptional-control of gad expression : H-NS prevents gad expression during the exponential growth whereas the alternative sigma factor RpoS relieves H-NS repression during the stationary phase , directly or indirectly accounting for transcription of gad genes . [10383761]
  • These results indicate that H-NS is involved in the negative transcriptional regulation of the gad genes and raise the possibility that H-NS would directly silence the gadA and gadB promoters and/or indirectly repress gad expression through the control of trans-acting factors , probably the stationary-phase factor ss . [10383761]
  • Apart from the gadBC operon , the most important genes involved in acid resistance are present within the acid fitness island ( AFI ) , a 15 kb region both repressed by H-NS and under the control of RpoS [ 10,11 ] . [21034467]
  • H-NS was first identified as a transcription factor by Jacquet and co-workers [ 2 ] and is involved in many general processes such as control of genes involved in osmoregulation and virulence ( for reviews see [ 3 , 4 ] ) . [7748928]
  • These included several additional genes , including the hde locus and many genes involved in ﬂagella formation , previously known to be under H-NS control . [17881364]
  • H-NS and RpoS are involved in the transcriptional-control of gad genes Fig. 4 . [10383761]
  • The previously reported strong derepression of acid resistance genes in hns mutants involves gadX ( 28 ) and most likely reﬂects the strong negative regulation of S by H-NS ( 5 , 69 ) . [15716429]
  • H-NS controls the regulation of carbohydrate and amino acid utilization genes . [17526711]
  • H-NS regulon genes and their regulation by environmental parameters . [11298273]
  • Therefore , multiple systems ( EnvZ/OmpR , Cpx , Rcs , and H-NS ) appear to be involved in sensing environmental osmolarity , leading to sophisticated regulation of the curli genes . [15743952]
  • Mutations in hns result in various phenotypes , because H-NS is involved in the regulation of a variety of genes . [14973023]
  • This suggests that H-NS plays an indirect role in the regulation of many genes identified in this study and further supports a high position of H-NS in the regulatory hierarchy of bacterial physiology . [11298273]
  • Despite possible pleiotropic effects , first of all , we provide strong experimental evidence that H-NS plays a direct role in the regulation of this acid resistance system , identifying gadA and gadX as target genes responsive to H-NS control . [15795232]
  • Lucchini S , Rowley G , Goldberg MD , Hurd D , Harrison M , Hinton JC : H-NS mediates the silencing of laterally acquired genes in bacteria . [18405378]
  • Similarly , the virulence regulon in V. cholerae , which is a veritable mosaic of ancestral and horizontally acquired genes , uses H-NS as a transcriptional repressor of imported genes52 ,103,104 . [15100692]
  • For a number of other genes , H-NS has been shown to act as repressor . [9632265]
  • H-NS acts as a repressor of most of these genes , which include gadX , gadW , and gadE ( 17 ) . [16980449]
  • H-NS represses a large number of genes that constitute the rpoS regulon in the exponential phase ( 2 ) . [22843842]
  • Discussion H-NS has generally been considered a nonspecific silencer of many genes . [16204188]
  • H-NS might control many genes by participating in other global networks . [8152423]
  • Stem-loop 2 decreases the translation of H-NS and also the ability of H-NS to repress transcription of rcsA and other H-NS-repressed genes ( 13 , 26 ) . [11222598, 11222598]
  • The H-NS binding motif is associated with not only the genes encoding the structural genes of ﬂagella but also with the speciﬁc sigma factor ( ﬂiA ) and anti-sigma factor ( ﬂgM ) genes for regulating ﬂagella biosynthesis . [17881364]
  • In contrast , the hns-118 strain TP504 showed no flagella ( Fig. 2B and D ) H-NS afects the transcription of the flagellum biosynthesis The so-called deep-rough of E. coli known genes . [8071234]
  • The limited number of genes which have been studied in detail are derepressed in hns mutants , which has led to H-NS being called a ` silencer ' or ` repressor '' of transcription ( see below ) . [7748941]
  • Expression of FlhDC is tightly regulated by multiple transcription factors , including CRP , H-NS and OmpR , and hence the genes of the ﬂagellar cascade are regulated in response to many different environmental inputs ( Shin and Park , 1995 ; Sout-ourina et al. , 1999 ) . [19843224]
  • Phase variation of the fimA promoter as well as transcription of the fim genes is influenced by several global , environmental regulators ; for example , H-NS reduces the frequency of phase variation [ 9 ] and stimulates the transcription of fimA in a locked switched-on mutant [ 10 ] . [18545668]
  • Additional regulators acting on some of these genes include transcription factors speciﬁc for certain stress response , such as OxyR , and also some more global regulators , such as H-NS or Lrp ( Hengge-Aronis , 1996b and references herein ) . [9663683]
  • Indeed , the more stress-responsive genes are studied , the more it appears that their regulation involves a network of global regulators , such as H-NS or Lrp , but also CRP , IHF or Fis . [9663683]
  • For instance , combined evidence from our work and that of others shows that Fis mediates the regulation of other transcription regulators , such as GadE , CusR ( Table 2 ) , cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , H-NS and HU ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ; Gonzalez-Gil et al. , 1998 ) . [17768236]
  • After leucine-responsive protein , H-NS and σs , NhaR and RcsB are the fourth and ﬁfth regulators of osmC transcription to have been identiﬁed The participation of so many factors in the regulation of osmC illustrates the notion of cooperation of global regulators in the ﬁne-tuning of stress-inducible genes ( Bouvier et al. , 1998 ; Hengge-Aronis , 1999 ) . [11577158]
  • Transcription factors may be global or local in scope depending on various parameters including the numbers of genes that they regulate , their propensity to be involved in combinatorial control , and the numbers of environmental conditions in which they are active .10 One of the global regulators of transcription in E. coli is the protein called H-NS , whose regulatory scope extends to 20 % of the genes encoded by the genome .11 -- 13 H-NS is a small protein of 137 amino acids , which recognises DNA that is A+T - rich in sequence12 ,14,15 and/or specific DNA geometries such as intrinsic bending16 -- 18 and Holliday 19 junctions . [23661089]
  • Additionally , these genes are regulated by transcription factors speciﬁc for certain stress responses ( e.g. , OxyR , which is involved in the oxidative stress response ) or more-global regulators , such as H-NS , IHF , cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) - cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , and Lrp ( 104 ) . [16760308]
  • For example , several global regulators , such as cyclic AMP receptor protein and H-NS affect transcription of the cps genes ( 12 ) . [8763957]

  • Identification of a cold shock transcriptional enhancer o Escherichia coli gene encoding nucleoid protein H-NS ABSTRACT The hns ( 27 min ) gene encoding the 15.4-kDa nucleoid protein H-NS was shown to belong to the cold shock regulon of Escherichia coli , its expression being enhanced 3 - to 4-fold during the growth lag that follows a shift from 37C to 100C . [1961761]
