  • DsrA RNA regulates translation of RpoS message by an anti-antisense mechanism , independent of its action as a antisilencer of transcription ABSTRACT DsrA RNA regulates both transcription , by overcoming transcriptional silencing by the nucleoid-associated H-NS protein , and translation , by promoting efficient translation of the stress s factor , RpoS . [9770508]
  • Riboregulation in Escherichia interactions at multiple loci ABSTRACT DsrA is an 87-nt untranslated RNA that regulates both the global transcriptional silencer and nucleoid protein H-NS and the stationary phase and stress response sigma factor RpoS ( ss ) . [9770507]
  • DsrA inhibits the synthesis of the predominant nucleoid protein and global transcriptional silencer H-NS ( 13 ) and enhances the translation of the stationary phase and major stress response sigma factor RpoS ( ss ) ( 14 ) . [9770507]

  • Expression of the virulence plas-mid-carried apyrase gene ( apy ) of enteroinvasive Escheri-chia coli and Shigella ﬂexneri is under the control of H-NS and the VirF and VirB regulatory cascade . [10383761]
  • A phage infectiondependent regulation of the CRISPR response has been reported to occur in Streptococcus thermophilus or Thermus thermophi-lus ,31,32 and crRNAs are among the most abundant sRNAs in Streptococcus pyogenes .33 In contrast , in E. coli K12 , the crRNA level is nearly undetectable under laboratory growth condition ,12,13 while the type I-F CRISPR system in E. coli LF82 has been reported to be constitutively active and to limit the transformation of target plasmid DNA .34 In E. coli K12 , the transcriptional inhibition of Cascade expression by H-NS has been shown to be responsible for the dormant crRNA maturation .13 Consistently , the transcriptional regulator LeuO , a well-known anti-silencer of H-NS , has been identified as an activator of the CRISPR system , inducing Cascade gene transcription and concomitantly crRNA maturation .21 Thus , the upregulation of the LeuO protein was considered to be one factor triggering the CRISPR defense in E. coli . [23392250]
  • DISCUSSION Previously , the presumptive transcriptional regulator YjjQ of E. coli has been implicated in virulence of the avian pathogenic E. coli strain IMT5155 ( 6 ) , and yjjQ expression has been shown to be regulated by H-NS and LeuO ( 12 ) . [26078445]
  • Expression of the yjjQ gene , which is encoded in the yjjQ-bglJ operon , is repressed by the global repressor H-NS and activated by the pleiotropic transcriptional regulator LeuO , as shown for the laboratory E. coli K-12 strain ( 12 ) . [26078445]

  • K5 Capsule Gene Cluster , and Expression of slyA in Escherichia In this paper , we present the first evidence of a role for the transcriptional regulator SlyA in the regulation of transcription of the Escherichia coli K5 capsule gene cluster and demonstrate , using a combination of reporter gene fusions , DNase I footprinting , and electrophoretic mobility shift assays , the dependence of transcription on the functional interplay between H-NS and SlyA .   • Similarly , H-NS is involved in several cellular functions in E. coli and related organisms . [11278074]
  • H-NS is required for normal thermoregulation of different genes involved in pathogenesis , e.g. , the E. coli * Corresponding author . [8655536]
  • Consistent with this role , H-NS was found to be a negative transcriptional regulator of micF and regulates ompF expression post-transcription-ally through micF .54,55 On the other hand , H-NS negatively regulate ompC expression transcriptionally .54 H-NS has been implicated in the thermoregulation of genes in E. coli and related bacteria .53,56,57 An intriguing question is whether H-NS is involved in thermoregulation of micF expression No studies have been done with an hns deletion strain to determine if thermoregulation is lost in this genetic background . [11601842]
  • For instance , H-NS or H-NS-like proteins , global regulators that down regulate genes responsive to environmental conditions [ 22 ] , have been shown to repress the expression of almost all E. coli cryptic ﬁmbriae and several Cup ﬁmbriae of P. aeruginosa [ 10 , 18 ] . [21344461]
  • Most importantly , H-NS is a global regulator of a variety of unrelated genes in E. coli ( 2 , 31 , 58 ) as well as being involved in virulence expression in pathogenic Shigella ( 35 ) , Salmonella ( 21 ) , and enteroinvasive E. coli ( 7 ) strains . [9352908]
  • H-NS is a global regulator of a variety of unlinked and unrelated genes in E. coli and Salmo-nella typhimurium ( 2 , 43 ) . [9922259]
  • The expression of virulence genes in the LOCUS OF ENTEROCYTE EFFACEMENT ( LEE ) pathogenicity island of enteropatho-genic E. coli is repressed by H-NS . [15100692]
  • It is known that the expression of a variety of genes is repressed by H-NS , and mutations in hns result in various phenotypes , but the role of H-NS in the drug-resistance of Escherichia coli has not been known . [14973023]
  • In this paper , we report that H-NS controls the multidrug-resistance of E. coli by regulating the expression of drug exporter genes . [14973023]

  • Results Repression of the bgl operon by H-NS H-NS represses the wild-type bgl operon encoding the positive regulator BglG , the b-glucoside speciﬁc permease BglF ( or EIIBgl ) , and the phospho-b , D-glucosidase BglB ( Fig. 1 ) ( Defez and de Felice , 1981 ; Schnetz et al. , 1987 ; Higgins et al. , 1988 ) .   • H-NS : A UNIVERSAL REGULATOR The effect of the bacterial heat-stable nucleoid-structuring ( H-NS ) protein on gene-expression is overwhelmingly negative and extends throughout the genome , pointing to an almost universal role for this nucleoid-associated protein as a transcriptional repressor . [15100692]

  • In E. coli , operons caiTABCDE and fixABCX are modulated positively by general regulators , such as the AMPc receptor protein ( CRP ) or the transcriptional regulator responsible for anaerobic induction ( FNR ) , and negatively by the DNA-binding protein H-NS , glucose , or nitrate ( Eichler et al. , 1994a ; Unden and Trageser 1991 ) . [14595781]
  • CHR activity was always high because the cai operon ( responsible for the expression of carnitine-metabolism ) was controlled by protein regulators such as FNR ( transcriptional regulator under anaerobic conditions ) , catabolic repression via protein receptor ( CRP ) of AMPc , histones ( H-NS ) , and the transcriptional factor j 2 ( RpoS ) , which is expressed when the cell reaches the stationary phase of growth and inhibits carnitine-metabolism ( Eichler et al. , 1996 ) . [14595781]
  • H-NS was originally isolated as a nucleoid-associated protein ( Jacquet et al. , 1971 ; Cukier-Kahn et al. , 1972 ; Spassky et al. , 1984 ) and repeatedly isolated as a transcriptional regulator of numerous genes ( Goransson et al. , 1990 ; May et al. , 1990 ; Falconi et al. , 1991 ; Kawula and Omdorff , 1991 ; Shi et al. , 1993 ; Bertin et al. , 1994 ; Levinthal et al. , 1994 ; Sledjeski and Gottesman , 1995 ) . [8670904]
  • H-NS is a 15 kDa protein that acts as a regulator of more than 200 E. coli genes mostly related to adaptation to environmental stress ( Drlica and Rouviere-Yaniv , 1987 ; Hulton et al. , 1990 ; Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ) . [17892462]
  • The H-NS protein is thought to play a major role in the condensation of genome DNA into the compact nucleoid because of its curved DNA-binding activity ( Yamada et al. 1991 ) and its abundancy ( 22 000 molecules/cell or 1 H-NS dimer for each 440 bp DNA ) ( Talukder et al. 1999 ) and thereby acts as a global transcription repressor for a number of genes ( for reviews see Drlica & Rouviere-Yaniv 1987 ; Pettijohn 1988 ; Atlung & Ingmer 1997 ) . [10947847]
  • A recent study has demonstrated that in E. coli K12 transcription from the casA and CRISPR I promoters is repressed by heat-stable nucleoid-structuring protein ( H-NS ) ( Pul et al. , 2010 ) , a global repressor of transcription in many Gram-negative bacteria . [20659289]

[8455549]

  • Overproduction of the nucleoid protein H-NS also leads to nucleoid condensation and a strong inhibition of transcription and translation , and results in a drastic loss of cell viability ( Spurio et al. , 1992 ) . [12123448]

  • Factors required for motility and full flhDC expression include cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) and cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Soutourina et al. , 1999 ) , histone-like nucleoid-structuring ( H-NS ) protein ( Bertin et al. , 1994 ) , the heat shock response network proteins DnaK , DnaJ and GrpE ( Shi et al. , 1992 ) , Pss and Psd , which are involved in the synthesis of phosphatidy-lethanolamine in cell membranes ( Shi et al. , 1993 ) , and inorganic polyphosphate ( Rashid et al. , 2000 ) .   • H-NS is an abundant , approximately 15 kDa nucleoid-associated protein that is present at about 20 000 copies per genome equivalent and is a well-known silencing protein that represses expression of cryptic genes such as the bgl operon involved in b-glucoside utilization ( Dorman and Deighan , 2003 ; Dole et al. , 2004 ; Dorman , 2004 ) . [20345943]

  • As mentioned above , the CS7 .4 protein has been identified as the factor present in extracts of cold shock cells responsible : ; : ~ the transcriptional enhancement of hns recognizing a i i0 bp DNA fragment ( fig I ) containing the - 1 0 and - 3 5 elements of the promoter and a CCAAT motif located between the transcriptional startpoint and the first few codons of H-NS [ 6 ] * Correspondence and reprints In the present paper we investigated whether additional signals for CS7 ,4 might exist upstream of its I 10 bp target and determined the effects of CS7 .4 on the accessibility of this DNA fragment to DNase I. Finally , to determine the relevance of a conserved CCAAT motif in eliciting the cold shock enhancement we investigated the cold inducibility of the hns promoter derived from Proteus vulgaris which , unique among the known Enterobacteriaceae hns genes ( fig I ) , lacks this motif , Our results indicate that no additional cold shock signal is present in the hns promoter , at least within 550 bp upstream the 110 bp fragment constituting the main target and that cold shock induction in vivo can occur also in the absence of a CCAAT sequence . [7748932]

Pon Laboratory of Genetics , Department of Biology MCA , University of Camerino , 62032 Camerino ( MC ) , Italy ( Received 21 December 2000 ; accepted 15 January 2001 ) Abstract -- The promoter of hns , the structural gene for the abundant nucleoid-associated protein H-NS of Escherichia coli , contains , downstream of the initiation site , two four bp-long ` CG clamps ' , one of which overlaps the potential target sequence ( CCAAT ) of CspA , the cold-shock transcriptional enhancer of this gene .   • In either case , H-NS is not acting as a classical repressor since we do not believe that it recognizes a speciﬁc consensus sequence . [9352908]
  • Because of the angular distortion of the promoter sequence by bound H-NS molecules , the sub-optimal spacing of the - 1 0 and - 3 5 regions is no longer able to make stable contacts with the polymerase surface ( Travere , 1989 ) . [7512187]
  • A. DNase I footprint analysis of the 246 bp ftnA promoter sequence ( both sense and antisense strands ) with and without the addition of 1 mM H-NS . [20015147]
  • Using hdeABp as a model promoter , we observed with purified components that H-NS , acting at a sequence centered at − 118 , selectively repressed transcription by E 70 . [16204188]
  • Fis that binds to a degenerate consensus sequence was initially discovered as a factor in site-speciﬁc DNA inversion reactions ( Johnson et al. , 1988 ; Koch et al. , 1988 ) and later found to function in transcriptional activation of tRNA and RNA operons ( Nilsson et al. , 1990 ; Ross et al. , 1990 ; Condon et al. , 1992 ) as well as transcription factor H-NS ( Falconi et al. , 1996 ) . [9680219]
  • One H-NS dimer binds to each 15 -- 20 bp ( Amit et al. , 2003 ) and bridges adjacent tracts of DNA , resulting in lateral condensation of large regions and formation of large globular structures ( Dame et al. , 2005 ) . [20466769]
  • Instead , Hha binds to H-NS , which binds to speciﬁc regions of regulatory sequences in this operon ( Nieto et al. , 2000 ; Madrid et al. , 2002 ) . [17116239]
  • This finding prompted us to propose a model in which H-NS may function as a transcriptional regulator through its ability to bind to curved DNA sequences , which are found in regions upstream of a certain subset of E. coli promoters ( Tanaka et al. 1991a ) . [8455549]
  • The finding that H-NS binds to both synthetic and naturally occurring curved D N A sequences supports the idea that H-NS may function as a global regulator by recognising local alterations in DNA curvature ( Yamada et al. 1990 ; Tanaka et al. 1991 ) . [8152423]
  • H-NS recognizes DNA with a certain configuration , such as curved DNA generated by stretches of AT-rich sequence ( AT tracts ) rather than a specific sequence ( Rimsky et al. 2001 ; Rimsky 2004 ) . [16204188]
  • H-NS binds DNA without any obvious sequence speciWcity but displays preferential binding to DNA that is curved and/or more Xexible than random DNA ( Dame et al. , 2001 ; Jordi et al. , 1997 ) . [16879983]
  • H-NS binds preferentially to sequences that are high in A1T content ( Lucht et al. , 1994 ) and contain bent DNA ( Yamada et al. , 1990 ; Owen-Hughes et al. , 1992 ; Falconi et al. , 1993 ; Zuber et al. , 1994 ) . [11123679]
  • H-NS is a highly abundant protein that binds to DNA with a preference for AT-rich sequences ( 34 ) . [22843842]
  • H-NS has a preference for binding AT-rich DNA sequences ( Navarre et al. , 2006 ) . [20659289]
  • H-NS binds to DNA with a preference for bent and AT-rich sequences ( Ussery et al. , 1994 ; Schröder and Wagner , 2002 ) . [15066043]
  • It has previously been shown that H-NS binds to PhlyE in regions upstream ( H-NS I ) and downstream ( H-NS II ) of the transcript start site , and that a SlyA binding site overlaps H-NS I ( Westermark et al. , 2000 ; Wyborn et al. , 2004b ) . [17892462]
  • Therefore , it is suggested that H-NS ﬁrst binds at AT-rich regions up - and downstream of the hlyE transcript start site ( Wyborn et al. , 2004b ; Fig. 7 , A ) . [17892462]
  • Taken together these data suggested that at lower concentrations H-NS may bind at AT-rich speciﬁc nucleation sites , and at higher concentrations , multiple H-NS proteins oligomerize to occupy both the upstream and downstream regions of PhlyE . [17892462]

  • The current view of the mechanism of H-NS-mediated repression is that H-NS binds as a dimer to AT-rich and planar-bent DNA sequences and then forms an extended oligomeric complex on the DNA , which represses transcription initiation when located next to a promoter . [16207917]
  • When H-NS acts as a silencer or repressor it binds to AT-rich , curved sequences and thereby blocks transcription of the gene in question ( 6 ) . [11053378]

  • We propose here that H-NS bound to the AT tract centered at − 118 nt ( nucleation site ) laterally extends by cooperatively recruiting H-NS molecules to the downstream sequence joined through DNA wrapping around E 70 , which results in trapping of E 70 in a DNA loop . [16204188]
  • Hence , the gene silencer AT8 ( an H-NS nucleation site ) serves as a crucial driving force for triggering the transcription regulatory effect , but the rest of the DNA sequence in the region determines the distance and the directionality of the effect . [15582999]
  • H-NS shows the typical extended protection with no sharp borders , centring within the region of the strongest DNA curvature , extending into the core promoter sequence and covering a stretch of nucleotides downstream of the transcription start site . [16238633]

  • H-NS can repress cydAB expression from an upstream sequence element H-NS protects DNA regions located both upstream and overlapping the cydAB promoters . [11123679]
  • These data are consistent with models of transcriptional silencing in which the curved DNA sequence to which H-NS initially binds is located upstream or downstream of the promoter that is to be repressed81 . [15100692]
  • H-NS was found to bind preferentially to a curved DNA sequence upstream of the hns gene in E coil and furthermore this curved region was shown to be necessary for autoregulation of H-NS [ 15 ] . [7748941]
  • The H-NS protein has been shown to bind preferentially to intrinsically curved DNA ( 38 ) , for which the sequence characteristic is phased A tracts of 4 to 6 bp ( 11 ) . [8655536]
  • DISCUSSION By combining DNA footprinting data from different sources , we have identiﬁed a DNA sequence that correlates with H-NS binding at speciﬁc locations in the E. coli genome . [17881364]
  • The nucleotide sequence in the possible upstream regulatory region exhi-bits short homopolymeric dA and dT stretches , which can act as curved DNA sequences binding to the E. coli histone-like protein H-NS ( Tanaka et ai , 1991 ) . [7815937]
  • The apparent promiscuity of H-NS probably arises from the fact that it does not have a consensus sequence for DNA binding , but instead has a consensus structure . [15100692]
  • The Cnu-H-NS protein complex binds to a specific sequence at the origin of chromosomal DNA replication in Escherichia coli [ 1 ] . [23028867]
  • H-NS , a non-specific DNA binding protein , binds to a specific sequence of oriC once complexed with Cnu [ 1 ] . [23028867]
  • Although there is ample evidence that H-NS binds preferentially to DNA containing curved regions , we show here that a major basis for this selectivity is the presence of a conserved sequence motif in H-NS target transcriptons . [17881364]
  • H-NS binds to no specific target sequence in DNA but instead recognizes intrinsic DNA curva ¬ 3 The abbreviations used are : PR1 , region 1 promoter ; X-gal , 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl - - D-galactopyranoside ; EMSA , electrophoretic mobility shift assay . [17827501]
  • We tested whether H-NS binds to this bent DNA sequence of lrp by DNA mobility shift experiments . [7603430]
  • These results indicated that H-NS binds specifically to a bent DNA region of lrp . [7603430]
  • Rather than binding directly to specific DNA sequences in the hly operon , Hha exhibits nonspecific DNA binding ; therefore , it was proposed Hha binds to H-NS , which binds to specific regions of regulatory sequences in the hly operon [ 17 ] . [18545668]
  • H-NS favors binding to DNA sequences that have the propensity to bend ( 101 ) , but there is no deﬁnitive DNA sequence that is recognized by H-NS , and it binds with considerably less speciﬁcity to rRNA promoters than expected for a classical repressor . [15568992]
  • LRP and H-NS bind to the same DNA sequences , yet they differ in binding mechanisms In comparison with H-NS , which also binds to all seven rRNA P1 promoter upstream regions ( Hillebrand et al. , 2005 ) , LRP complexes were formed at notably lower ( 2-to 20-fold ) protein concentrations . [16238633]
  • H-NS preferentially binds to two DNA regions , one of which includes sequences that map upstream of the known binding sites for the transcription factors that regulate the expression of nrdA ( FIS and IciA ) ( Fig. 5B ) . [23873909]
  • ( A ) Logo representation of the experimentally determined H-NS binding motif derived from sequences in Table 1 . [17881364]
  • We tested severarlestriction fragments that carry theextended H-NS binding site in proV and different lengths of proU upstream sequences in a two-dimensional gel electrophoresis assay that can resolve DNA fragments according to their size and conformation ( Fig. 7 ) . [8120010]
  • We therefore wondered whether theextended H-NS binding site at the 5 ' end of the E. coli proV gene also consists of curved DNA sequences . [8120010]
  • Based on this definition , an H-NS nucleation site is distinct from other ordinary H-NS-preferred binding DNA sequences . [15582999]
  • Other ordinary H-NS-binding DNA sequences may lead to the binding of H-NS , but in the absence of an H-NS nucleation site , the bound H-NS is not necessarily well organized and hence is not transcriptionally repressive ( 31 ) . [15582999]
  • 0002-8080 G 2005 SGM Printed in Great Britain Silencing involves two sites ( Dole et al. , 2004b ) : H-NS represses transcription initiation at the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - dependent promoter by binding to an AT-rich and presumably bent upstream silencer sequence ( Schnetz , 1995 ; Singh et al. , 1995 ; Schnetz & Wang , 1996 ; Mukerji & Mahadevan , 1997 ) . [16207917]
  • A Cis-spreading Nucleoprotein Filament Is Responsible for the Bacterial Gene Silencing -- In addition to the nucleation site , the rest of the AT-rich DNA sequence in S. typhimurium or E. coli LCR-I appears to also possess a certain binding preference for H-NS because , with increasing H-NS concentrations , some of this AT-rich DNA was occupied by H-NS as well ( Figs. 8 -- 10 ) . [15582999]
  • This sequence element is similarly AT-rich as the CRISPR leader regions and according to ChIP-chip analysis harbours H-NS sites in addition to RNA polymerase binding sites ( Oshima et al. , 2006 ) . [20132443]
  • However , by combining recent ﬁndings we derive here an AT-rich sequence motif for directing sequence-speciﬁc DNA binding by H-NS . [17881364]
  • This sequence is highly A/T-rich and is therefore consistent with other reported binding targets for H-NS . [9749677]
  • This sequence is AT rich ( 68.4 % ) , a feature typically found in other well-character-ized H-NS binding regions . [23873909]
  • H-NS binds to the AT-rich sequence within the 200 bp sequence upstream from the csgD promoter , and interferes with the binding of RNA polymerase ( data not shown ) . [20466769]
  • H-NS binds to DNA with no obvious sequence specificity , but specific binding sites tend to be AT-rich and intrinsically bend ( 13 -- 16 ) , as also observed for the upstream silencing region of the bgl operon ( 6 , 8 , 17 ) . [12077137]
  • Once H-NS is recruited to the local site ( the AT-rich DNA sequence element , AT4 ) , the binding cooperativity of H-NS may cause a cis-spreading ( oligomerization ) of H-NS to the promoter region . [11121424]
  • H-NS binds to upstream pnir sequences and represses FNR-dependent transcription We noted that the pnir upstream region contains a number of AT-rich tracts of sequence that are phased such that this region might be intrinsically curved . [10972841]
  • The DNA sequences of both fragments are AT rich , and in addition , the upstream fragment includes DNA sequences identical to the H-NS consensus sequence region described previously ( 41 ) . [23873909]
  • Interestingly , in the presence of LeuO the extended protection by H-NS is no longer visible ( Fig. 3B , compare lanes 2 and 4 ) , indicating that due to LeuO binding the DNA region containing the H-NS high-affinity binding site is no longer protected from DNase I cleavage , in agreement with decreased cooperative binding ( Fig. 3A ) . [20659289]

  • Binding of H-NS and LRP to the rrnB UAS occurs in a synergistic fashion The observation that both proteins , LRP and H-NS , are able to bind individually to the same rrn P1 promoter upstream DNA elements immediately raises the question whether or not the two proteins recognize the same binding sites and potentially compete each other , or if they were able to bind simultaneously , possibly at different faces of the DNA helix , or even stimulate the binding of each other in a cooperative manner . [16238633]

  • While a degenerated DNA consensus sequence has been characterized for LRP -- DNA interaction ( Brinkman et al. , 2003 ) , the view of a conserved DNA sequence for H-NS binding has been abandoned , although a high content of A : T base pairs is consistently found within H-NS binding sites . [16238633]
  • These sites include a majority of sequences containing the sites ATAAA ( 56 % ) and AATAA ( 68 % ) , which form part of the highafinity H-NS binding motifs identified by computational analysis by Lang et al. 83 and Kahramanoglou et al. 12 respectively . [23661089]
  • The sizes of the H-NS binding sites on the ftnA promoter vary from 10 to 35 bp which resembles the protection pattern of H-NS within other promoters , e.g. proU , ﬂhDC and synthetic promoters ( Lucht et al. , 1994 ; Soutourina et al. , 1999 ; Rimsky et al. , 2001 ) . [20015147]
  • The H-NS binding sites in the ftnA promoter are AT-rich with all sites containing > 65 % AT content and displaying an average AT content of 80 % , much greater than the genomic average of ~ 50 % and consistent with the marked preference of H-NS for AT-rich sequences ( Lucht et al. , 1994 ; Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ; Grainger et al. , 2006 ; Lucchini et al. , 2006 ; Lang et al. , 2007 ) . [20015147]

  • Transcriptional monocopy lacZ fusion studies showed that both operons are coexpressed during anaerobic growth in the presence of carnitine , respond to common environmental stimuli ( like glucose and nitrate ) , and are modulated positively by the same general regulators , CRP and FNR , and negatively by H-NS . [9573142]
  • In E. coli , operons caiTABCDE and fixABCX are modulated positively by general regulators , such as the AMPc receptor protein ( CRP ) or the transcriptional regulator responsible for anaerobic induction ( FNR ) , and negatively by the DNA-binding protein H-NS , glucose , or nitrate ( Eichler et al. , 1994a ; Unden and Trageser 1991 ) . [14595781]
  • This difference in regulation of bgl versus stpA and proU by H-NS-I119T and StpA may further imply that growth conditions which induce stpA may allow the maintenance of strong repression of bgl , even if H-NS is less active under such conditions . [16980475]

[1453957]
  • Finally , proU synthesis is derepressed by an osmotic upshift in part by release of the abundant nucleoid-associated protein H-NS from an extended regulatory sequence located downstream from its promoter ( Lucht and Bremer 1994 ; Gowrishankar and Manna 1996 ; Jordi et al. 1997 ) . [10601034]
  • This conﬁrms that H-NS will repress gadA and gadBC ; however , this control did not require gadX as reported for the W3110 strain and was not even evident in a gadX culture ( data not shown ) . [12446650]
  • A recent report has dem-onstrated that H-NS may work to repress the gadA and gadBC genes by repressing gadX ( 20 ) . [12446650]
  • As shown in Fig. 4B , fragments 2 and 4 were shifted very efﬁciently by H-NS ; fragment 2 encompasses the predicted bend region located between the divergent yjjP and yjjQ promoters , while fragment 4 was mapped to a position downstream of the yjjQ promoter ( from positions 7 to 193 relative to that of the yjjQ transcription start site , which was mapped to 158 bp upstream of yjjQ ) ; fragment 1 , which encompasses the yjjP promoter and sequences located downstream to it ( from position 80 to 163 relative to that of the yjjP transcription start at 113 bp upstream of yjjP ) was also shifted speciﬁcally ( Fig. 4B ) ; fragment 3 , which encompasses the yjjQ promoter was not shifted compared to that of the lacZ control fragment , which suggests that in this region no sites or only weak H-NS sites are present . [18055596]
  • Furthermore , the expression level directed by a yjjP promoter-lacZ fusion that encompasses the complete intergenic region ( from position 450 to 182 relative to that of the transcription start site mapping to a position 113 bp upstream of yjjP ) increased from 33 units in the wildtype strain to 263 units and 211 units in the hns and the hns leuO double mutants , respectively ( Fig. 5B ) , demonstrating that in the complete context , H-NS represses the yjjP promoter eightfold and suggesting that H-NS also binds in between the yjjP promoter and the yjjP gene . [18055596]
  • To analyze whether downstream sequences alone confer regulation by H-NS and/or StpA , the stpA coding region [ stpA ( orf ) ] ( including positions 1 to 466 relative to the transcription start ) was inserted between the constitutive lacUV5 promoter and the lacZ gene ( Fig. 1E ) . [16980475]
  • Possibly , LeuO has a dual role in the regulation of the yjjP promoter ; it may repress the promoter directly and also counteract its repression by H-NS when the binding site downstream of the yjjP promoter is present . [18055596]
  • It is also possible that H-NS traps RNA polymerase at the yjjQ promoter by binding upstream and downstream and that LeuO prevents the formation of that repressing DNA loop . [18055596]
  • It is possible , and not unprecedented , that H-NS binds downstream of the transcriptional start site and still affects transcription . [9352908]
  • Translation of bglG reduces the H-NS mediated repression via the downstream silencer It is possible that repression by H-NS via the downstream silencer affects transcription initiation at any promoter ( bgl and lacUV5 were tested ) located upstream . [15066043]
  • Repression by H-NS via the downstream silencer requires termination factor Rho , is enhanced when translation of the bglG gene is prevented , and is promoter independent . [15066043]
  • H-NS binding to two target sequences located at a distance apart has been reported for most H-NS-modulated operons ( 17 , 42 ) , and it is not uncommon that one of the binding sites maps downstream of the promoter , as is the case for the bgl operon ( 43 ) . [23873909]
  • H-NS mediated repression via the downstream silencer.The inﬂuence of the downstream silencer was analysed by its insertion in between the constitutive lacUV5 promoter ( UV5 ) and the lacZ gene . [15066043]
  • The repression of the bgl operon by H-NS was analysed using chromosomally encoded bgl-lacZ fusion , which carry the bgl promoter including the upstream and the downstream silencer and its deletion derivatives . [15066043]
  • Discussion The approximately 100-fold repression of the bgl operon by H-NS requires an AT-rich and presumably bent silencer sequence located directly upstream of the CRP-depen-dent bgl promoter , and a downstream silencer located within the coding region of the ﬁrst gene , bglG . [15066043]
  • The experimental data reported here are consistent with gene silencing models in which the curved DNA to which H-NS initially binds is located upstream or downstream of the promoter that is to be repressed ( Rimsky , 2004 ) . [17892462]
  • The protection by H-NS at site I was lost , as was protection at sites V and VI , which are located on and just downstream of the promoter . [20015147]
  • Although it is possible that there are other promoters much further upstream which read through into the stpA region but which were not detected in this experiment due to inefﬁcient extension over long distances , it seems likely that the transcriptional start at 241 is the primary stpA promoter in vivo and is strongly repressed by H-NS . [9006049]
  • It should be noted that our data do not allow us to discern whether H-NS remains bound to the cydAB promoter region in microaerobiosis or whether it still has a repressing role under these conditions . [11123679]
  • This suggests that in vivo , the most important role played by GadX ( GadW ) on the gadA promoter is as an H-NS countersilencer , not as a transcriptional activator . [18808381]

  • Regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ Operon , Encoding LuxR-Type Transcription Factors , and the Divergent yjjP Gene by H-NS and LeuO † Thomas Stratmann , S. Madhusudan , and Karin Schnetz * Institut für Genetik , Universität zu Köln , Zülpicher Str . [18055596]
  • The divergent arrangement of transcription units at the yjjP-yjjQ-bglJ locus raises the possibility that transcription-induced supercoiling ( 34 ) plays a role in its antagonistic regulation by H-NS and LeuO , which again would relate to autoregulation of the leuO gene ( 20 , 21 , 62 ) . [18055596]
  • The yjjQ and bglJ genes encoding LuxR-type transcription factors form an operon whose repression by H-NS is counteracted by LeuO . [18055596]
  • Stratmann , T. , Madhusudan , S. , and Schnetz , K. ( 2007 ) Regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ operon encoding LuxR-type transcription factors and the divergent yjjP gene by H-NS and LeuO . [20132443]
  • Stratmann , T. , Madhusudan , S. , and Schnetz , K. ( 2008 ) Regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ operon , encoding LuxR-type transcription factors , and the divergent yjjP gene by H-NS and LeuO . [19843219, 20659289, 22295907]
  • Stratmann , T. , Madhusudan , S. and Schnetz , K. ( 2008 ) Regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ operon , encoding LuxR-type transcription factors , and the divergent yjjP gene by H-NS and LeuO . [24335284, 20965974]
  • However , while the relevance of LeuO and YjjQ for pathogenicity indicates that their genes are expressed under certain in vivo conditions in the host environment , both the leuO gene and the yjjQ-bglJ operon are repressed by H-NS under laboratory growth conditions ( 6 , 55 ) . [20952573]
  • However , expression of leuO and bglJ is repressed by H-NS , at least under laboratory growth conditions . [20952573]
  • YjjQ was provided plasmidically , as expression of the native yjjQ-bglJ operon is repressed by H-NS during exponential growth under laboratory conditions ( 12 ) . [26078445]
  • Furthermore , the data support the conclusion that LeuO , whose expression is likewise repressed by H-NS and which is a virulence factor in Salmonella enterica , is a master regulator that among other loci , also controls the yjjQ-bglJ operon and thus indirectly the presumptive targets of YjjQ and BglJ . [18055596]
  • Here we show that yjjQ and bglJ form an operon carried by E. coli K-12 , whose expression is repressed by the histone-like nucleoid structuring ( H-NS ) protein . [18055596]
  • The results show , furthermore , that H-NS represses the expression of this yjjQ-bglJ operon . [18055596]
  • Transcription of the yjjQ-bglJ operon is repressed by the global repressor H-NS ( heat-stable nucleoid structuring protein ) , and it is activated by the pleiotropic transcriptional regulator LeuO ( 12 ) . [26078445]
  • Expression of the yjjQ gene , which is encoded in the yjjQ-bglJ operon , is repressed by the global repressor H-NS and activated by the pleiotropic transcriptional regulator LeuO , as shown for the laboratory E. coli K-12 strain ( 12 ) . [26078445]
  • A further parallel is that both the rcsA gene and the bglJ gene ( within the yjjQ-bglJ operon ) are repressed by H-NS . [20952573]
  • Furthermore , the yjjP gene , encoding a membrane protein of unknown function and located upstream in divergent orientation to the yjjQ-bglJ operon , is likewise repressed by H-NS . [18055596]
  • The yjjP gene located upstream of the yjjQ-bglJ operon and in a divergent orientation is likewise repressed by H-NS but is not activated by LeuO . [18055596]
  • Taken together , the data conﬁrm the regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ operon by H-NS and LeuO , and they demonstrate the repression of yjjP by H-NS . [18055596]
  • Here we show that yjjQ and bglJ are expressed as an operon , which is repressed by H-NS and activated by LeuO . [18055596]
  • RESULTS H-NS represses and LeuO activates the yjjQ-bglJ operon . [18055596]
  • Regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ operon by H-NS and LeuO adds an additional aspect to the role of LeuO in the emerging regulatory network important for in vivo induction of genes and for pathogenicity . [18055596]
  • However , regulation of the yjjQ-bglJ operon by H-NS and LeuO indicates that these genes are related to the control of stress responses and/or virulence-associ-ated traits ( 15 , 18 , 19 ) . [26078445]
  • Further , it was proposed that LeuO acts as a positive regulator of the leu operon and leuO gene with activation based on transcription induced changes in DNA supercoiling and delimiting of H-NS spreading by LeuO ( Fang and Wu , 1998b ; Chen et al. , 2003 ; Chen and Wu , 2005 ) . [22295907]
  • For Regulation of rRNA transcription by H-NS and LRP 873 instance , H-NS is involved in the LRP-dependent activation of the ilvIH operon ( Levinthal et al. , 1994 ) . [16238633]
  • Similarly , the bgl operon , encoding the gene products necessary for the uptake and fermentation of aryl-b , D-glucosides is repressed ~ 100-fold by H-NS ( Higgins et al. , 1988 ; Lopilato and Wright , 1990 ; Schnetz , 1995 ; Caramel and Schnetz , 1998 ) . [15066043]
  • Results Repression of the bgl operon by H-NS H-NS represses the wild-type bgl operon encoding the positive regulator BglG , the b-glucoside speciﬁc permease BglF ( or EIIBgl ) , and the phospho-b , D-glucosidase BglB ( Fig. 1 ) ( Defez and de Felice , 1981 ; Schnetz et al. , 1987 ; Higgins et al. , 1988 ) . [15066043]
  • A negative regulatory element ( NRE ) is located within the ﬁrst gene of the proU operon and constitutes a speciﬁc binding site for H-NS ( 13 , 34 , 41 , 42 ) . [8626294]
  • The proU operon , encoding an uptake system for the osmoprotectants glycine-betaine and proline , is repressed very speciﬁcally ( ~ 70-fold ) by H-NS in vivo . [15066043]
  • The second , downstream level of bgl operon repression by H-NS is not affected by LeuO , BglJ or RpoS/Crl . [16207917]
  • The E. coli bgl operon is one example of a system whose repression by H-NS is exceptionally speciﬁc . [16207917]
  • The bgl ( aryl - , D-glucoside ) operon of E. coli is a classical example of a locus that is tightly repressed by H-NS . [20952573]
  • In addition , the pap operon is controlled by cAMP-CAP and also regulated by H-NS [ 301 . [7748928]
  • Hence , it is not surprising that H-NS does not play a role in the temperature-dependent regulation of this operon . [23873909]

  • Another common feature shared by the gsp and chiA genes and the bgl operon is the fact that their transcription is silenced by H-NS ( Defez and De Felice , 1981 ) . [11118204]
  • E. coli does not normally ferment - glucosides such as salicin because of silencing by H-NS and transcription termination within the bgl operon ( Bglo cryptic phenotype ) . [15576773]

[11133959]
  • Na - induced transcription of nhaA , which encodes an Na / H anti-porter in Escherichia coli , is positively regulated by NaR and affected by H-NS . [12867437]
  • Consistent with this assignment , a number of genes transcribed by EsS in stationary phase are silenced by H-NS in the exponential phase ( Barth et al. , 1995 ) and hchA was recently identiﬁed as a sS-dependent gene in two independent microarray studies ( Patten et al. , 2004 ; Weber et al. , 2005 ) . [16796689]
  • A common denominator for the genes known to be regulated by H-NS ( e.g. regulation of genes at stationary growth phase , starvation , changes in high osmolarity , low temperature shock , and altered DNA topology ) seems to be their involvement in different kinds of stress . [7512187]
  • Such an observation is consistent with the function of H-NS at osmotic shock or the regulation of genes expressed under stationary phase ( Higgins etai , 1988 ; Hengge-Aronis , 1993 ) , Thus H-NS may link rRNA expression to situations of rapid osmotic changes or reduced growth at stationary phase or even be effective under conditions of cold shock ( La Teana etai , 1991 ) , Obviously , acellular process as central as the regulation of rRNA synthesis must be controlled by many different parameters and sensors to be as effective and efficient as observed . [7512187]
  • H-NS has been referred to as a general transcription silencer , since it represses a large number of genes , which are not required during the exponential phase of growth under normal laboratory conditions . [16204188]
  • The major nucleoid proteins , HU , IHF , H-NS and Fis , in exponential growth phase E. coli under aerobic conditions are all known to have functional dichotomy ( 5 ) . [20156994]
  • Expression of Dps is known to be regulated by OxyR , in response to oxidative stress ( 2 ) , and three nucleoid proteins , IHF , Fis , and H-NS , in response to growth phase ( 2 , 8 ) . [21239586]
  • Expression of 19K , 17K , IOK-L , and IOK-S is under the control of H-NS at the transcriptional level To determine whether H-NS affects transcription of the genes coding for 19K , 17K , 10K-L , and 10K-S , cells harboring the set of promoter-lacZ fusion genes were grown until the mid-logarithmic and stationary phases , and then the / 3-galactosidase activity expressed by the cells was measured . [8455549]
  • Expression was induced to nearly the same extent in both strains , ﬁvefold in the wild type and fourfold in the mutant , suggesting that H-NS does not play a major role in stationary-phase induction of appY . [8655536]
  • Thus , the silencing of csgD by H-NS should be reduced in stationary phase because of the increase in IHF level ( see Fig. 2 ) . [20466769]
  • The present work revealed that the P2 promoter of nhaA is a stationary phase-induced promoter which is activated by sS and neither NhaR nor Na1 or H-NS is involved in this induction ; in the stationary phase , transcription from P2 increased dramatically , and this increase was eliminated in an rpoS mutant strain ( Fig. 6A ) but not in a DnhaR strain ( Fig. 6B ) . [11133959]
  • Both Fis and H-NS selectively repress the dps promoter , preventing transcription initiation by RNA polymerase containing s70 , the housekeeping s factor , but not by RNA polymerase containing s38 , the stationary-phase s factor . [18452510]
  • Interestingly , the three genes rcsA , gadE and bglJ , respectively , encoding the three RcsB heterodimerization partners are all repressed by H-NS ( Majdalani and Gottesman , 2005 ; Stratmann et al. , 2008 ; Sayed and Foster , 2009 ) . [22295907]

  • Apart from the gadBC operon , the most important genes involved in acid resistance are present within the acid fitness island ( AFI ) , a 15 kb region both repressed by H-NS and under the control of RpoS [ 10,11 ] . [21034467]
  • In the 20-kb genomic region ( from yddS to ydeN ) encompassing the gadBC operon , none of the genes is known to be H-NS repressed or acid induced . [16980449]

  • Transcription from the distal promoter , osmCp1 , is independent of S and is repressed by both the leucine-responsive protein and H-NS in minimal me-dium ( 4 ) . [12867437]

  • Expression of the leuO gene is repressed by H-NS , and it is upregulated in stationary phase and under amino acid starvation conditions . [22295907]
  • However , the leuO gene is also repressed by H-NS and only moderately induced by branched amino acid starvation in a ppGpp-depen-dent manner ( 19 ) . [20952573]

  • The divergent yjjP gene is likewise repressed by H-NS . [18055596]
  • The expression directed by the divergent yjjQ and yjjP promoters is repressed by H-NS . [18055596]

  • First , the leuO gene itself is repressed by H-NS and is positively autoregulated ( 5 , 6 , 26 ) . [18055596]
  • H-NS is one of the major factors involved in silencing the bgl promoter ( 16 , 25 , 31 ) ; both loss-of-function mutations in the hns gene and mutations that disrupt H-NS binding upstream of the bgl promoter activate the bgl operon . [22843842]

  • To confirm that H-NS does indeed affect its own transcription , the hns gene was introduced into the hns deletion strain CU237 on a plasmid . [8437561]
  • Though this appears to suggest a form of molecular backup between two homologous proteins , the backup is unequal : whereas the DstpA mutant hardly affects gene expression , a Dhns mutant leads to upregulation of at least 500 genes as agreed upon by several studies .12,13,15,34 Whereas the absence of stpA does not visibly affect in vivo DNA binding of H-NS on a genomic scale , that of hns abolishes binding of StpA to about two-thirds of its wildtype binding regions .32 Though both H-NS and StpA repress each other 's transcription , leading to the up-regulation of one in the absence of the other , the degree of up-regulation conferred on StpA by the absence of H-NS may not be suficient to compensate for the lack of H-NS .30 This in part might be due to the higher susceptibility of StpA to degradation by Lon in the absence of H-NS .33 A complete backup of H-NS activity by StpA might not be desirable as there are conditions , such as a late stationary phase , in which an attenuated H-NS is favoured .36 The close relative of E. coli , Salmonella enterica Typhimurium , encodes three H-NS-like proteins . [23661089]

  • RESULTS H-NS Binds to the proU Control Region-DNA segments located upstream and downstream of the proU promoter are known to influence proU expression ( 17 , 26 , 51 , 60 ) . [8120010]
  • As an example , H-NS acts upstream of its own promoter to autoregulate its expression . [7748941]
  • Both cai and ® x operons require the presence of FNR and CRP for their expression , while they are partially repressed by H-NS ( Eichler et al. , 1995 ; Buchet et al. , 1998 ) . [10564497]
  • The expression of the gad system and hdeAB is repressed by a nucleoid protein H-NS during the exponential growth phase ( Yoshida et al. , 1993a , b , c ; De Biase et al. , 1999 ) . [12694615]
  • The expression of leuO is likewise repressed by H-NS , and not detectable during exponential growth ( Klauck et al. , 1997 ; Chen et al. , 2004 ) . [16207917]
  • Remarkably , expression of the leuO gene is itself repressed by H-NS under standard laboratory growth conditions ( Klauck et al. , 1997 ; Chen et al. , 2001 ) . [22295907]
  • H-NS is an abundant , approximately 15 kDa nucleoid-associated protein that is present at about 20 000 copies per genome equivalent and is a well-known silencing protein that represses expression of cryptic genes such as the bgl operon involved in b-glucoside utilization ( Dorman and Deighan , 2003 ; Dole et al. , 2004 ; Dorman , 2004 ) . [20345943]
  • The gadB and gadC genes form an operon and a number of factors , including H-NS , RpoS and CRP-cAMP , are involved in the transcriptional control of gad expression ( Castanie-Cornet & Foster , 2001 ; De Biase et al. , 1999 ; Rowbury , 1997 ; Rowland et al. , 1984 ) . [14702398]

[9749677]
  • CHR activity was always high because the cai operon ( responsible for the expression of carnitine metabolism ) was controlled by protein regulators such as FNR ( transcriptional regulator under anaerobic conditions ) , catabolic repression via protein receptor ( CRP ) of AMPc , histones ( H-NS ) , and the transcriptional factor j 2 ( RpoS ) , which is expressed when the cell reaches the stationary phase of growth and inhibits carnitine metabolism ( Eichler et al. , 1996 ) . [14595781]
  • The expression of gadX is activated by the alternative sigma factor RpoS during the stationary phase of growth [ 15,19,21 ] , but is repressed during the exponential phase by the nucleoid protein H-NS due to its binding to the gadX promoter or its destabilizing effect on RpoS [ 23-25 ] . [21314918]

  • In summary , Hsp31 expression is highly sensitive to the growth temperature and H-NS plays an important role in modulating Hsp31 concentration in exponential phase cells , silencing hchA transcription more efﬁciently as the temperature decreases while allowing RNA polymerase access to its EsD - and EsS-dependent promoters in times of thermal stress . [16796689]

  • H-NS is best known for its ability to repress or silence the expression of a large number of genes in E. coli and other enterobacteria by acting at the level of transcription initiation of these genes . [21602341]
